encodingDesc.p: bios are still work in progress and a bit messy in places.

ID construction is based on name initials: uses full initials where known for married women include maiden surname initial if known if firstname [or surname for that matter] unavailable use x then add number to ensure uniqueness
any "tbd" IDs are waiting to be verified

TODO: roleName, forename, need finessing. esp @type=... title? improvements to dates notBefore/notAfter listRelation - also once name tagging and biographies are complete wikidata etc linkage to do once name tagging and internal linkage is completed

change.desc: updated to include new bios for books 2 and 3. added sources.
slight revision to schema (persName label); revised format of label names. added EDTF date formatting for births and deaths.

noteGrp.note: Alice Thornton (1626-1707) was born to Christopher and Alice Wandesford in Kirklington, North Yorkshire on 13 February 1626. She was their fifth child of seven and their youngest daughter. She married William Thornton (1624-68) of East Newton on 15 December 1651, and they had nine children, three of whom survived to adulthood. A widow from the age of 44, she died at East Newton and was buried at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave on 1 February 1707.

list.item: ‘Pedigree of the Family of Wandesford’ in McCall, Wandesforde Family, n.p.

noteGrp.note: Christopher Wandesford (1592-1640) was the eldest son and heir of Sir George and Catherine Wandesford. He was born at Bishop Burton, East Riding on 24 September 1592. He attended Clare College, Cambridge but was required to return home on his father's death to provide for his siblings. He married Alice Osborne, and they had seven children, five of whom survived childhood, including Alice Thornton. He was MP for Yorkshire in the 1620s. In 1633 he relocated the family to Dublin, Ireland, to serve as Master of Rolls. In 1640 he was briefly Lord Deputy of Ireland before he died on 3 December 1640.

list.item: Pogson, 'Wandesford, Christopher (1592–1640), Politician and Administrator,' ODNB

noteGrp.note: Roger Lasselles, born c. 1557, was rector of St. Michael’s, Kirklington from May 1590 until his death in July 1630. He baptised Alice Thornton there in 1626. He died on 21 July 1630.

list.item: McCall, Parish Registers of Kirklington, pp. 13, 41

noteGrp.note: Anne Norton (1593-1683) was the daughter of Sir George and Catherine Wandesford; Alice Thornton’s paternal aunt. She married Maulger Norton on 4 March 1622. They had five children; three sons and two daughters. She was buried on 23 December 1683 at St Mary’s, Richmond.

list.item: ‘Pedigree of the Family of Wandesford’ in McCall, Wandesforde Family, n. p.

noteGrp.note: This is possibly Olive Best (1594-1654), the daughter of John and Anne Mallory, baptised 5 December 1594. She had a twin sister, Jane. Olive became the second wife of Thomas Best of Middleton Quernhow, MP for Ripon, on 17 January 1619. She died without issue and was buried at St. Mary’s, Wath on 16 June 1654.

list.item: Walbran and Raine, Memorials of Fountains, vol. 2 part 1, pp. 327-8
Foster, Pedigrees of Yorkshire, vol. 2 p. 36

noteGrp.note: Sarah Tomlinson was a servant in the Wandesford household in the early 1630s who was with them during their time in London. We have not been able to trace her further.

Christopher Wandesford (1628-87) was the son of Christopher and Alice Wandesford, born on 2 February 1628 and baptised at St. Michael’s Kirklington on 14 February. He was Alice Thornton's younger brother. He married Eleanor Lowther on 30 September 1651, and they had 12 children. He became heir on his brother George’s death in 1651 and was made 1st Baronet of Kirklington on the Restoration of Charles II in 1660. He was elected MP for Ripon in 1679 and again in 1680. He died in London on 23 February 1687 and was buried on 12 March at St. Michael’s, Kirklington.

list.item: McCall, Parish Registers of Kirklington, p. 67

noteGrp.note: Mr Baxter was a man acquainted with the Wandesford family who lived in Kent in the 1630s. We have not been able to trace him further.

This is probably Lady Katherine Leveson (1598-1674), the daughter of the illegitimate son of the Elizabethan courtier Robert Dudley - also called Robert - and his first wife Alice, born 1598. After being abandoned by her father, her mother lived at Dudley House, St. Giles-in-the-Field, which was a stone's throw from where the fire broke out at the Wandesford resident on St. Martin's Lane in the early 1630s. She married Sir Richard Leveson, later MP for Newcastle-upon-Lyme, in 1609 at Kenilworth. She died February 1674 at Trentham, Kent without issue, and in her will endowed almshouses and an education fund which survives to this day at Temple Balsall.

list.item: Adams, 'Dudley, Sir Robert (1574–1649), Mariner and Landowner', ODNB.

persName.roleName: Sir, 1st Lord Raby; 1st Earl of Strafford

noteGrp.note: Thomas Wentworth, 1st Lord Raby, 1st Earl Strafford (1593-1641) was born on 13 April 1593 to William Wentworth, a Yorkshire landowner, and his wife Anne; he was their second and eldest surviving son and heir. He was a childhood friend of Christopher Wandesford, Alice Thornton's father, both being educated by the Dean of Ripon. His first marriage to Margaret Clifford took place in 1611 and she died childless in August 1622. He married Arabella Holles in February 1625, and they had a son and two daughters. After her premature death on 6 October 1631, he married Elizabeth Rhodes in 1632 and had another son and daughter. In 1633 he was made Lord Deputy of Ireland and relocated to Dublin. He was recalled to England in 1639, fell out of favour with the King, impeached and executed on 12 May 1641.

list.item: Asch, 'Wentworth, Thomas, First Earl of Strafford (1593–1641), Lord Lieutenant of Ireland', ODNB

noteGrp.note: Lady Anne Watson (1627-96) was the eldest daughter of Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl of Strafford and his second wife Arabella, born on 8 October 1627 in Finningley, Nottinghamshire. A childhood friend of Alice Thornton's in Dublin, she married Edward Watson on 24 November 1654, and they had eight children, four sons and four daughters. She died on 2 January 1696 and was buried at Rockingham parish church.

list.item: Wise, Rockingham Castle and the Watsons, p. 91

noteGrp.note: Lady Arabella McCarthy, born in October 1630 in London, was the daughter of Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl of Strafford and his second wife, Arabella. A childhood friend of Alice Thornton's in Dublin, she married Justin MacCarthy, 1st Viscount Mountcashell, about 13 years her junior. She was still alive (but ill) on 14 April 1697, when mentioned in a letter of Alice Thornton to Abstrupus Danby, and died without issue.

list.item: Burke and Burke, Extinct and Dormant Baronetcies, p. 577
Wauchope, 'MacCarthy, Justin, First Viscount Mountcashel (c. 1643–1694), Army Officer', ODNB
'Alice Thornton to Abstrupus Danby, 14 April 1697', ZS, NYCRO
Earl of Strafforde’s Letters, ed. Radcliffe and Knowler, vol. 2 p. 430p

noteGrp.note: John Wandesford (c. 1630-1664) was the fourth, but third surviving, son of Christopher and Alice Wandesford; brother of Alice Thornton. He was born c. 1630 and moved to Ireland with the family as a young child when his father became Master of the Rolls. After returning to Yorkshire, he was educated at schools in Bedale, Chester and Richmond, before entering Christ's College, Cambridge (1649-51). Becoming ill at Cambridge, he moved to London. He was elected MP for Richmond in 1661 and died in his lodgings at London on 2 December 1664 of an ague. He was buried at St. Augustine’s, Broxbourne, Hertfordshire.

list.item: Bolton and Watson, 'Wandesford, John (c.1632-64), of Kirklington, Yorks. and London,' HPO

noteGrp.note: Frank Kelly was an orphan boy taken into the household of Christopher Wandesford in Dublin, after Wandesford had encountered him while playing bowls on the green. He stayed with the family and moved with them to Chester in 1641. He was about nine when he died of smallpox at Chester in 1643.

Thomas Danby of South Cave was the second son of Thomas and Elizabeth Danby of Braworth, born c. 1617. He was possibly the same Thomas Danby involved in a court of chivalry case in 1638 against John Bates of York, whom he claimed had verbally abused him and denied his gentility. He fought for the Royalists in the 1640s and was killed at the Battle of Naseby on 14 June 1645.

list.item: Cust and Hopper, '148 Danby v Bates', BHO

noteGrp.note: Dr Mahum, described by Thornton as her 'old doctor', may be the same Richard Mahum who witnessed her mother's will in 1659. We have not been able to trace him further.

list.item: 'Will of Alice Wandesforde' in McCall, Wandesforde Family, pp. 357-8

noteGrp.note: Katherine Danby (1615-45) was the eldest child of Christopher and Alice Wandesford; older sister of Alice Thornton. She was baptised on 20 October 1615 at St. Michael the Archangel, Kirklington. She married Thomas Danby in July 1630, aged 14. She was pregnant 16 times but suffered six stillbirths. Of the couple's 10 baptised children, eight were boys and two were girls; seven of her 10 children survived infancy. She died on 10 September 1645, aged 29, at Thorpe Perrow of postpartum complications. She was buried at St. Mary’s, Masham the next day.

list.item: 'Dates of birth of the children of Sir Thos & Katherine Danby 1631-1645', ZS, NYCRO
'Memorandum of evidence for date of marriage of Sir Thos Danby & Katherine Wandesford in July 1630', ZS, NYCRO

noteGrp.note: Francis Danby was the youngest son of Thomas Danby and Katherine Wandesford, born at Thorpe Perrow on 27 August 1645. He was Alice Thornton's nephew, named after his brother who had died the month before. His mother died shortly after his birth from postpartum complications. He was still alive in April 1672 when he was named in his older brother Charles's will.

list.item: 'Dates of birth of the children of Sir Thos & Katherine Danby 1631-1645', ZS, NYCRO

noteGrp.note: Edmund Norton (1622-48) was the second son of Maulger and Anne Norton; he was Alice Thornton's cousin. He attended Cambridge University and was admitted to Gray's Inn to study law in February 1646. He served as a colonel of dragoons under John Mallory in the Skipton garrison in the 1640s. He married Jane Dudley and died of a pleurisy. He was buried at St-Michael-le-Belfrey, York on 29 November 1648.

list.item: Collins, Registers of St. Michael-le-Belfrey, vol. 1 p. 228

noteGrp.note: Toby Dudley, born c. 1597, was the oldest son and heir of Ambrose Dudley of Chopwell, Northumberland. He married Jane Blackiston, and they had one child, Jane. He was buried at Holy Cross, Ryton in 1661.

list.item: Dugdale, Pedigrees recorded at Durham, p. 109

noteGrp.note: Jane Clavering, birth date unknown, was the daughter and sole heir of Toby and Jane Dudley of Chopwell. She married Edmund Norton on 10 February 1647. After his death in 1648, she married Robert Clavering at St Ebba’s church, Ebchester on 15 July 1651. They had four children, two sons and two daughters. She died in 169o.

list.item: Bourn, History of the parish of Ryton, p. 164

noteGrp.note: Charles I of England (1600-49), born 19 November 1600 to James I and VI and Anne of Denmark, was King of England, Scotland and Ireland from 1625 and the reigning monarch for the first 23 years of Alice Thornton's life. He married Henrietta Maria and had nine children, four sons and five daughters. He was executed on 30 January 1649.

list.item: Kishlansky and Morrill, 'Charles I (1600–1649), King of England, Scotland, and Ireland', ODNB.

noteGrp.note: Julianne Norton (1633-49), born 6 January 1633, was the daughter of Maulger and Anne Norton; she was Alice Thornton's cousin. She died age 17 on 9 April 1649 at her father's house St. Nicholas, Richmond and was buried the next day at St Mary's parish church.

John Norton was the fourth son of Maulger and Anne Norton of St. Nicholas, Richmond; he was Alice Thornton's cousin. Born c.1637, he died at the family home at St Nicholas, Richmond of a consumption in 1646, aged nine.

Sir Edward Osborne (1596-1647), 1st Baronet Kiveton, was the son of Sir Hewett and Joyce Osborne, baptised on 12 December 1596; he was the maternal uncle of Alice Thornton. Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge, he was admitted to the Inner Temple in study law in 1620. He was knighted and created Baronet by James I that same year and was vice president of the Council of the North. He married twice, first, on 13 October 1618 to Margaret Belasyse, with whom he had a son and, second, after her death in 1624, to Anne Walmesley, widow of William Middleton, with whom he had another son. He died on 9 September 1647 at his family home of Kiveton Hall, South Yorkshire, according to Thornton from a surfeit of cold melons.

list.item: 'Pedigree of Osborne, Duke of Leeds' in Foster, Pedigrees of Yorkshire vol. 3, n.p.
London Metropolitan Archives, St Benet Gracechurch, Composite register: baptisms 1558/9 - 1730, marriages 1558 - 1730, burials 1558 - 1730, P69/BEN2/A/001/MS05671 – check these

noteGrp.note: George Wandesford (1623-51), born 14 September 1623, was Christopher and Alice Wandesford's eldest son and heir; he was Alice Thornton's brother. Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl of Strafford, was his godfather. He attended Trinity College, Dublin from 1636, when the family were living in Ireland. Accused of taking part in the battle of Marston Moor in July 1644, his estates were sequestered and he moved to Hipswell Hall, his mother's property, before fleeing to France for the remainder of the fighting in England. He drowned in the River Swale, Yorkshire, through which he was riding on horseback, on 31 March 1651. He was buried at St. Michael the Archangel, Kirklington.

list.item: Pogson, 'Wandesford, Christopher (1592–1640), Politician and Administrator,' ODNB
Whitaker, History of Richmondshire, vol. 2, p. 159

noteGrp.note: William Wandesford (1605-90) was the youngest son of Sir George Wandesford by his second wife, Mary; he was Alice Thornton's half-uncle. He was baptised on 26 August 1605 at St. Michael the Archangel, Kirklington. He married Rebecca Reade and they had a daughter, Catherine. His brother, Christopher, sent him to be an apprentice to a London merchant. He was granted an annuity of £20 for life on 30 June 1637 out of Wandesford property at Castlecomer, Ireland, paid yearly at Christ's Church, Dublin. He suffered severe losses during the wars of the three kingdoms due to his loyalty to the royal cause. On 31 July 1646 he declared he had been at Oxford when Castlecomer was held for the king and that he lent money but had not taken up arms. According to Thornton, a committee who advised Charles I during his trial met in his London home. He was made a gentleman-pensioner by Charles II after the Restoration in 1660 and died in 1690.

list.item: British Library, Letter from George Paul to Cox Macro, 10 May 1710, ff. 69v-70r. Add MS 32556: Cox Macro, DD: Correspondence and papers: 1700 – 1764

noteGrp.note: Mary Yorke, daughter and fourth child of Maulger and Anne Norton, was baptised at St. Mary’s, Richmond on 12 July 1635; she was Alice Thornton's cousin. On 20 August 1651 she married John Yorke, a knight of Gouthwaite, later MP for Richmond (1661-63). They had four children, three sons and a daughter. She became a widow in 1663 and purchased the manor of Beverley in 1675. We do not know when she died.

list.item: Bolton and Watson, 'Yorke, Sir John (c.1634-63), of Gouthwaite and Richmond, Yorks', ODNB
'Pedigree of Yorke, of Bewerley, co. York' in Foster, Pedigrees of Yorkshire, vol. 2, n.p.

noteGrp.note: Sir John Yorke was the son of John Yorke of Gouthwaite and his second wife, Catherine, born c. 1634. He was educated at Queen's College, Oxford, matriculating in 1650. On 20 August 1651 he married Mary, daughter of Maulger and Anne Norton, and they had four children, three sons and a daughter. He was knighted by Charles II on his Restoration in 1660. He was elected MP for Richmond the next year, to the Cavalier Parliament, a position he held until his death near London of a pleurisy on 1 April 1663, aged 29. He was buried at St Chad's church, Middlesmoor, Nidderdale; he is commemorated there by a Latin inscription.

list.item: Bolton and Watson, 'Yorke, Sir John (c.1634-63), of Gouthwaite and Richmond, Yorks', HPO

persName.roleName: Sir, Sheriff of Cumberland, 1st Baronet Lowther

noteGrp.note: Sir John Lowther, 1st Baronet Lowther (1606-75) and Sheriff of Cumberland was born on 20 February 1606 to Sir John and Eleanor Lowther. He graduated from the Inner Temple in 1621 and was called to the bar in 1630. He married Mary, daughter of Richard Fletcher of Hutton, Cumbria, before 1628; they had 11 children, five sons and six daughters. His second wife was Elizabeth Hare, by whom he had four children, three sons and a daughter. His eldest daughter with Mary, Eleanor, married Christopher Wandesford, Alice Thornton's brother. He was twice elected MP for Westmorland, in 1628-29 (with his father) and again in 1660. He fought for the royalists during the Wars of the Three Kingdoms. He died on 30 November 1675 and is buried at St. Michael’s church, Lowther alongside his father, also commemorated by a Latin inscription.

list.item: Helms and Naylor, 'Lowther, Sir John I, 1st Bt. (1606-75), of Lowther Hall, Westmld.', HPO

noteGrp.note: Eleanor Lowther (1633-1714) was the daughter of John Lowther, 1st Baronet Lowther and his first wife Mary, baptised on 23 March 1633 at St. Michael’s church, Lowther. She married Christopher Wandesford, Alice Thornton’s brother, on 30 September 1651 at Lowther. Christopher and Eleanor had nine children, three sons and six daughters. She was buried on 20 December 1714 at St. Michael the Archangel, Kirklington. Her will was proved on 23 December.

list.item: Burke, Extinct and Dormant Baronetcies, p. 551
Computer Printout of Lowther, Westmoreland, England. Salt Lake City, Utah: Genealogical Society of Utah, 1966. Print., item 7
'Will of Eleanor Wandesford' in Jackson, Autobiography, pp. 322-23

noteGrp.note: William Thornton (1624-68), the son of Robert Thornton of East Newton and his second wife Elizabeth, was born along with his twin brother Richard on 2 June 1624 and baptized at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave on 9 June. William married Alice Wandesford on 15 December 1651 at her mother’s house, Hipswell Hall. They had nine children, of whom three survived to adulthood. He died at Malton on 17 September 1668 and was buried at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave the next day.

Michael Syddall (1614-58) was baptised on 30 September 1614 at SS Martin and Gregory, York, the son of William Syddall, a baker, and his wife Margaret. He was admitted to Christ's College, Cambridge in 1631 at the age of 16, graduating with his BA in 1635 and MA in 1638. He married Ellen Hunton, widow of the steward of the late Christopher Wandesford. He was minister at St Michael's, Kirklington, 1644-49 and vicar of St Anne’s, Catterick, from 1645-58. He was buried on 8 January 1658 in the chancel at St Anne’s. In his will, dated 3 January 1658, he left money to build a school and he made William Thornton one of four trustees.

list.item: 'Parish Registers for the Archdeaconry of Yorkshire', PR/Y/MG/1, BIA, York
'Will of Michael Syddall' in McCall, Wandesforde Family, pp. 289-90

noteGrp.note: Alice Thornton's first child, an unnamed daughter, was born on 27 August 1652 but lived for less than an hour and so was not baptised. She was buried at St. Agatha’s, Easby the next day.

Alice Comber (1654-1721), nicknamed Nally, was born on 3 January 1654 at Hipswell Hall to Alice and William Thornton and baptised two days later. She was their second child and one of three Thornton children to survive to adulthood. She married Thomas Comber on 17 November 1668, by whom she had nine children (five sons and four daughters), with two sons and two daughters surviving childhood. She was Alice Thornton’s main heir in 1707 and inherited her books. She died on 20 January 1721 and was buried at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave two days later, where there is a memorial plaque.

list.item: Anselment, First Booke, passim Whiting, Comber, passim
'Will of Alice Thornton, 10 April 1705' in Jackson, Autobiography, pp. 332-9

noteGrp.note: Maulger Norton (1593-1673) was baptised on 25 March 1593 at All Saints, Wath, the first son and heir of Robert and Catherine Norton of St Nicholas, Richmond. He was elected MP for Richmond in the Short Parliament of 1640. He married Alice Thornton's paternal aunt, Anne, on 4 March 1622, by whom he had six children, four sons and two daughters. He was buried at St. Mary’s, Richmond on 12 December 1673.

Elizabeth (Betty) Thornton (1655-56) was born on 14 February 1655 to Alice and William Thornton and baptised on 16 February at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave. She was their third child. She died on 3 September 1656, aged 18 months, after becoming ill with an ague, and was buried at St. Anne’s, Catterick.

list.item: 'Catterick Parish Registers, Baptisms, Marriages & Burials 1653-1988, PR/CAT 1/1', NYCRO

noteGrp.note: Charles Anthony (1600-85) was born on 6 November 1600 and was educated at Jesus College, Cambridge (BA 1624, MA 1627). He was ordained in 1636 and became vicar of St Anne’s, Catterick in 1660. He baptised Alice Thornton's daughter, Elizabeth, in 1654. He died on 25 June 1685 and was buried at St Anne’s, Catterick.

Katherine Blackburne, baptised 26 January 1645 at Grinton, was the daughter of Roger and Anne Covell of Fremington. She married Timothy Blackburne. She stood in for Thornton’s mother, who was unwell, at the baptism of Thornton's daughter, Elizabeth, in 1654. A widow from 1694, she was still alive in 1696 when she was named executrix in her mother's will.

list.item: Poynton, Genealogical Memoranda Relating to the Family of Blackburne, p. 2 and 'Additions and Corrections', p. 1
Slingsby, Yorkshire Parish Registers: Grinton in Swaledale 1640-1807, p. 4

noteGrp.note: Elizabeth Gates (1597-1655), born 3 October 1597 at Buttercrambe, was the eldest daughter of Sir Richard Darley of Buttercrambe and his second wife, Elizabeth (née Gates). She became the second wife of Robert Thornton on 6 June 1618, and they had seven children, four sons and three daughters. After his death in 1637 she married Geoffrey Gates on 26 June 1638 at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave. Her joint-eldest son, William, married Alice Thornton. She died on 10 May 1655 at Oswaldkirk, from a 'voidance of blood' and was buried the next day at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave.

list.item: Anselment, First Booke, p. 246 nn342, 347, p. 250 n397

noteGrp.note: Geoffrey Gates was the second husband of Elizabeth Gates, whom he married on 26 June 1638 at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave, becoming the stepfather of William Thornton. In 1651 he refused to sign documents allowing his wife to dispose of her landed property, which meant William Thornton’s part of the marriage settlement with the Wandesfords was not legally binding. Gates died just eight days after his wife on 18 May 1655, and was buried at St Mary Lowgate, Hull the next day.

list.item: 'Letter from William Thornton to Lady Wandesford, 11 November 1651' in Jackson, Autobiography, pp. 287-88

noteGrp.note: Richard Thornton (1624-56), born on 2 June 1624 and baptised on 9 June, was the son of Robert Thornton and his second wife Elizabeth, and the twin brother of Alice Thornton's husband, William. He died unmarried in Dublin, Ireland of a bloody flux on 3 July 1656 and was buried at St Patrick's Cathedral the next day.

Katherine Danby (1656-1726) was the fourth daughter of Alice and William Thornton, and the second of the two that survived to adulthood. She was born on 12 June 1656 at Hipswell Hall and baptised the next day by Michael Syddall, probably at St. Anne’s, Catterick. In the later 1660s she was sent with her sister Nally to study at York. She married Thomas Purchas, rector, by arrangement of her brother-in-law, Thomas Comber, on 27 December 1682. She had five children by Purchas, three sons and two daughters. After Purchas's death in April 1697, she married Robert Danby of Northallerton in 1698, without her mother’s approval. She died on 17 December 1726 and was buried at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave.

list.item: Whiting, TC, vol. 1 pp. lvii, lxiii, 51, pp. 166-167
'Alice Thornton to Abstrupus Danby, 27 October 1698' [MIC 1274/6723], NYCRO

noteGrp.note: Katherine Best (1637-88) was the daughter of Thomas and Katherine Danby; she was Alice Thornton's niece. She was born on 25 May 1637 at Richmond. She married Henry Best of Middleton Quernhow sometime after 1659 and they had two children, a son and a daughter. She was widowed in 1674 and died in 1688.

list.item: ‘Pedigree of Best, of Elmswell and Middleton Quernhow’ in Foster, Pedigrees of the County Families of Yorkshire, vol. 3, n. p.
'Dates of birth of the children of Sir Thos & Katherine Danby 1631-1645', ZS, NYCRO

noteGrp.note: An unnamed Thornton son was born on 10 December 1657; the fifth child of Alice and William Thornton. He lived only half an hour after a difficult birth. He was buried at St Anne’s Church, Catterick the same day by Michael Syddall.

Robert Wittie (1613-84) was baptised at St Mary's, Beverley, on 14 November 1613, the son of George and Anne Wittie of Beverley. He studied medicine at King's College, Cambridge, and returned to Yorkshire to practice medicine, first at Hull and, from 1651 at the latest, at York. He treated Alice Thornton and her family for various ailments. Wittie wrote at least two books; 'The Antimonial Cup', on emetics, and 'Scarborough Spaw', which extolled the healing virtues of spas. He married Mary Hall (d. 1692). In 1675, when his mother died, he was resident in the parish of St Martin's, Coney Street, York. On his retirement from active profession, he moved to London and was incorporated at the Royal College of Physicians on 30 September 1680. He died in October 1684.

list.item: Munk, 'Robert Wittie b. 1613 d. October 1684', Inspiring Physicians

noteGrp.note: Alice Wandesford (1593-1659) was the daughter of Hewett and Joyce Osborne of Kiveton, born in 1593 in Isleham, Cambridgeshire. She married Christopher Wandesford and they had seven children, of which five survived to adulthood, including Alice Thornton. She joined her husband in Dublin with her young children in 1633. Widowed suddenly in December 1640, she and her children fled back to northern England after the Irish rebellion of 1641, living from 1644 until her death at her jointure property, Hipswell Hall. She died on 10 December 1659, after falling ill on 17 November, and was buried at St. Anne’s Church, Catterick. Her will was proved in January 1660, in which she left her plate, jewels, linens, books, writings, musical instruments and a portrait of her husband to her daughter Alice Thornton, to be handed down to her granddaughter Alice Comber on her death.

list.item: The Will of Dame Alice Wandesford', in McCall, Wandesforde Family, pp. 357-58

noteGrp.note: Peter Samways (1615-93) was born in 1615 in Eltham, Kent. He attended Westminster School and then Trinity College Cambridge, where he gained his MA in 1641. He was ordained Deacon of Rochester in 1643. A loyal monarchist, he was nevertheless presented to the rectory of Wath in the North Riding in 1658 on petition to Cromwell. With the Restoration in 1660, he was created Doctor of Divinity at Cambridge, and was made prebendary of Barneby, York in 1668. A friend of Alice Thornton and correspondent of her son-in-law, Thomas Comber, he died on 6 April 1693 at Bedale and was buried at St. Gregory’s Church.

list.item: Vallance, 'Samwaies [Samways], Peter (1615–1693), Church of England Clergyman', ODNB

noteGrp.note: John Kearton, birth date unknown, received his BA from Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge. He was ordained deacon at York in 1628, and priest in 1629. He became rector of St. Mary’s Richmond in 1657. Alice Thornton's mother, Alice Wandesford, wanted him to preach at her funeral service in 1659. In April 1660 he baptised, and then shortly afterwards buried, Alice Thornton's sixth child, William, at St. Agatha, Easby. He was buried on 18 August 1664 at St Mary’s, Richmond.

list.item: 'Parish Register of St. Mary, Richmond 1660-78', PR/RM 1/3, NYCRO

noteGrp.note: Daphne Lightfoot entered the service of the Wandesford family as an unmarried woman with the family name Cassell, possibly beginning in the household of Thornton’s sister, Katherine Danby, being with her when she died after childbirth in 1645 at Thorpe Perrow. She was then in the service of Alice Wandesford, and before 1654, she married another servant of Wandesford’s, George Lightfoot. The couple had at least one child, a daughter named Mary. Daphne prayed with Wandesford at her bedside in 1659, and she and her husband were witnesses to her will, in which they were left 20s each. After Lady Wandesford’s death, there are references to Daphne at East Newton Hall, helping out with duties such as wet-nursing Thornton’s daughter Elizabeth (Betty) in 1655, producing an inventory of goods after William Thornton’s death, and providing other support to Thornton during the tumultuous year of 1668. She was present with her daughter Mary at the private wedding of Thomas and Alice Comber on 17 November 1668. Daphne and her husband might still have been working at East Newton Hall in 1682 when he is mentioned in a letter from Thomas Comber to his mother-in-law. She was buried on 20 September 1689 at St. Agatha’s, Gilling West.

list.item: Comber, SS, vol I, p. 79, vol. II, p. 53
'The Will of Dame Alice Wandesford', in McCall, Wandesforde Family pp. 357-58
'Gilling West Parish Registers: Baptisms, Marriages and Burials, 1639-1782', PR/GIL 1/1, NYCRO

persName.roleName: 8th Lord Darcy de Knayth; 1st Earl Holderness

noteGrp.note: Sir Conyers Darcy, 1st Earl of Holdernesse, 8th Lord Darcy de Knayth (1599-1689) was born on 24 January 1599 to Sir Conyers and Dorothy Darcy. He was constable of Middleham Castle, Yorkshire, and created Earl of Holderness on 6 December 1682. On 14 October 1616 he married Grace, the only daughter and heir of Thomas Rokeby, of Skyers. They had six sons and five daughters, only one of the sons, Conyers, surviving childhood. He died on 14 June 1689 in Hornby, Yorkshire.
Hannah Ableson was a servant in Alice Thornton's household in the 1660s. We have not been able to trace her further.

Sir Robert Adair of Ballymenna and Kinhilt (1583-1655) was born in 1583 at Ballymena, co. Antrim, to Sir William and Rosina Adair. He was served heir to his father and grandfather in the Scottish estates on 19 February 1629. He was knighted by Charles I and became a Royalist soldier, before switching to the Scottish parliamentarians and became a major in the Earl of Leven's Horse Regiment. He commanded a regiment at the battle of Marston Moor in July 1644. Later, he commanded the cavalry at the 1650 Battle of Dunbar. He married Jane Edmonstone, and they had two sons and a daughter. He died on 1 March 1655 and was succeeded by his eldest son.

list.item: Furgol, A Regimental History of the Covenanting Armies, 1639-1651 (Edinburgh, 1990) pp
Terry, Papers relating to the Army of the Solemn League and Covenant, vol. 1 p. lv

noteGrp.note: George Anderson, a Scotsman, was a tutor to Thornton's brother George in France when he fled there after being sequestered after the battle of Marston Moor in 1644. We have not been able to trace him further.

Katherine Armitage (1612-67) was baptised at St. Peter, Leeds on 27 February 1612, the oldest daughter and second child of Thomas and Elizabeth Danby of Farnley. She married Francis Armitage, later 1st Baronet, in 1629. They had at least 11 children, five of whom, three sons and two daughters, can be identified. A widow from 1644, she attended Katherine Danby, her sister-in-law, on her death bed in September 1645. She was buried on 13 January 1667 at Wakefield Cathedral.

list.item: Leeds, St. Peter, Yorks, Family History Library [MIC 472196]

noteGrp.note: William Ayscough of Osgoodby (1648-76) was born on 9 March 1648 to Sir William and Judith Ayscough. He (or perhaps his father) was one of the coffin bearers at William Thornton's funeral in September 1668, and he married Alice Thornton's sister-in-law, Anne Thornton, on 27 January 1676. He died within a year of marriage and was buried on 20 November 1676 at All Saints, Thirkleby.

list.item: Watson, 'Ayscough (Askwith), Sir William (1614-95), of Osgoodby Grange, Thirkleby, Yorks.', HPO

noteGrp.note: Captain John Ashton (1613-42), baptised 19 September 1613 at the parish church of St. John, Preston was the son of Radclyffe and Elizabeth Ashton of Cuerdale Hall. He married Anne Shuttleworth, and they had one son. He was Captain of the Foot during the first English civil war which broke out in 1642. When Alice Thornton and her family fled Ireland in after the Irish Rebellion broke out in 1641, they were aided by Ashton on their journey through north-west England returning to Yorkshire. He died in October 1642 from wounds sustained at the Battle of Edge Hill.

list.item: Dugdale, Visitation of Lancaster, vol. 1, p.84, vol. 3 p. 272
Hodder, The registers of the Parish church of Preston, p. 8

noteGrp.note: Dr. Atie was a physician active in the Hambleton area in the late 1650s, perhaps an associate of Robert Wittie. We have not been able to trace him further.

John Bathurst (1597-1659) was baptised at St. Dunstan’s church in Mayfield, East Sussex on 21 August 1597, the son of John and Dorothy Bathurst. John was a doctor in Goudhurst, Kent. He matriculated from Pembroke College Cambridge in 1614 and became a Fellow of the Royal College of Physicians in 1637. He was incorporated at Oxford in 1643 and acted as physician to Oliver Cromwell. He was MP for Richmond in 1656 and 1658. He married Elizabeth Willance on 27 January 1636, and they had 10 children, seven sons and three daughters. Alice Thornton's mother sent her son Christopher to Dr. Bathurst at York when he suffered a distemper from grief over his father's death in November 1643, and her brother John was likewise sent to him when he dropped out of Cambridge University and moved to London in a state of melancholy. He died on 19 April 1659.

list.item: East Sussex Record Office; Brighton, England; Sussex Parish Registers, PAR 422/1/1/1

noteGrp.note: Martha Batte (1636-xxxx) was the daughter of John and Martha Batte, baptised at Birstall, Yorkshire on 29 September 1636. She and her family emigrated to a plantation in Charles County, Virginia in 1649, where she was still living in 1665 (she and her brothers were granted a land patent for transporting slaves). By 1667 she was back in Yorkshire in the service of the Countess of Sussex at Howley Hall. She was a friend of Alice Thornton's niece-by-marriage, Anne Danby, from their time in Virginia. Elsewhere in her writing Thornton identifies Martha as Mary Batte, her sister.

list.item: NYCRO, Cunliffe Lister Muniments. Anne Danby, An Accompt [MIC 2281]
Thwaite, Parish Register of Birstall, p. 2

noteGrp.note: Henry Best was the son of George and Grace Best of Middleton Quernhow. He married Katherine Danby, Alice Thornton’s niece, after 1659. In 1668 he was the beneficiary, along with three others, of a deed of William Thornton in relation to the settlement for Thornton’s daughters Alice and Katherine. He had two children by Katherine, a son and a daughter. A barrister at Gray’s Inn, he died there in January 1674.

list.item: Foster, Pedigrees of the County Families of Yorkshire p. n34
Settlement, 19 September 1667, William Thornton, Durham Cathedral Library CCOM-84

noteGrp.note: Thomas Binks was a man in the Richmondshire area in the late 1640s or 1650s who warned Alice Thornton of Jeremy (later Jerome) Smithson's plan to abduct her. He was possibly a relation of the Smithson family. Jane Smithson, Jerome's first cousin, married a Mr. Binks, and a Cousin Francis Binks is mentioned in Jerome's brother Hugh's will in 1672.

list.item: Smithson, Genealogical Notes and Memoirs of the Smithson Family, pp. 50, 114

noteGrp.note: Mr Binlows was a minister active in the Richmondshire area in the late 1650s. He may be Thomas Binlowes, preacher at Scruton, near Northallerton, from 1655.

Sir John Borlase was born c. 1576 in Cornwall to Edward and Suzannah Borlase. He attended Cambridge University, but did not graduate, and then pursued a military career. He fought extensively in the Low Countries in the early 17th century, becoming master-general of the ordnance of Ireland in 1634, and became Lord Justice of Ireland after the death of Alice Thornton's father Christopher Wandesford in 1640 along with Sir William Parsons. He married Alice (née Edwards), widow of Thomas Ravis, bishop of London, and they had three sons. He died at London on 15 March 1648 and was buried at Bartholomew-the-Great.

list.item: Clavin, 'Borlase, Sir John (c. 1576–1648), Army Officer and Politician', ODNB

noteGrp.note: John Bramhall (1594-1663) was baptised at St. Giles, Pontefract on 18 November 1594, one of six children of Peter Bramhall of Carleton. He graduated with a BA from Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge in 1612, and was ordained in York in 1615. On 24 June 1618, Alice Thornton's father Christopher Wandesford presented him to the rectory of South Kilvington, near Thirsk. On 10 November 1618 he married a clergyman's widow, Ellen Collingwood. The couple had six children, three sons and three daughters. Wandesford and Thomas Wentworth helped Bramhall secure the prebend of Huisthwaite, Yorkshire in 1632. He became Bishop of Derry, in Ireland, in May 1634, and was present at Christopher Wandesford's deathbed in December 1640. After Wandesford's death he was exiled and had returned to his native Yorkshire by 1642; and was restored in Ireland by Charles II in 1660. He died on 25 June 1663.

list.item: McCafferty, 'Bramhall, John (Bap. 1594, d. 1663), Church of Ireland Archbishop of Armagh', ODNB

noteGrp.note: Robert Brandling (1617-69) was the son of Robert and Mary Brandling of Felling. He was a royalist Colonel of the Horse during the Wars of the Three Kingdoms.
Mary Breakes was a servant in the Thornton household in the late 1660s. She married William Heard some time after she left the Thorntons' service. We have not been able to trace her further.

Sir William Brereton (1604–61), 1st Baronet, was born on 13 September 1604 to William and Margaret Brereton. A Puritan who owned extensive estates in Cheshire, and Member of Parliament for Cheshire at various times between 1628 and 1653, he was commander of Parliamentarian forces throughout the North Midlands during the First Civil War of 1642-47. He married twice; first, Susanna Booth in 1623, by whom he had four children, three daughters and a son; and, after her death, Cicely Mytton in 1641, a wealthy Staffordshire widow, by whom he had two more daughters. When the First Civil War ended, Brereton gave up his local offices and, although nominated as a judge, refused to attend the trial of Charles I in January 1649. He was elected to the Council of State in 1652 and 1653 but did not attend frequently, living in semi-retirement in London. He resumed his seat for Cheshire when the Long Parliament was reinstated in 1659, until its dissolution in March 1660, and died on 7 April 1661.

list.item: Morrill, 'Brereton, Sir William, First Baronet (1604–1661), Parliamentarian Army Officer', ODNB

noteGrp.note: Thomas Brockill was born c. 1617 in Richmond, the son of John Brockill, a glover. He matriculated at St John's, Cambridge in 1635 and obtained his BA in 1639. He was master of Richmond school 1642-5 and vicar of St Mary’s, Hornby, from 1650-69. He married Susanna (surname unknown), and they had a son. He was rector of St. Margaret’s, Tanfield from 1664 until his death and was buried there on 13 April 1669.
James Brodricke was footman for Alice Thornton's brother, George Wandesford, in the early 1650s. We have not been able to trace him further.

Benjamin Browne (1613-81) was the son of William Browne of Buckton, baptised at Bempton, East Riding on 28 June 1613. Thornton describes him as her ‘cousin Browne’ in one account, so it is possible that he was her kinsman, perhaps by marriage. He was educated at St John's Cambridge (BA 1639). He was instituted at St. Mary's, Masham in 1639 and made vicar there in 1645. His role was sequestered in the 1650s, and he was restored there after the Restoration in 1661. He was probably married since he and a Mrs Browne both attended Thornton in August 1662 at East Newton when she took communion. He was ordained priest at York in September 1662. He was buried on 11 December 1681.

list.item: Whitaker, History of Richmondshire vol. 2 p. 106

noteGrp.note: Joseph Browning was a coachman active in Dublin in the mid-1630s, possibly an employee of the Wandesford family. We have not been able to trace him further.
Mrs Bucke was possibly a servant in Alice Thornton's household or a local woman who was active in the Ryedale area in the mid-1660s. We have not been able to trace her further.

Cousin Bullock, a male relation of Alice Thornton, was probably a descendant of Launcelot Bullock of Holme who married Margaret Thornton, the daughter of William Thornton's great-grandmother, making him a cousin-by-marriage to Alice Thornton.
William Berridge was convicted of the murder of Thomas Danby, Alice Thornton's nephew, in a London tavern, in August 1667.

James Butler (1610-88) was born on 19 October 1610 to Thomas and Elizabeth Butler. He was an Anglo-Irish statesman and first Earl of Ormond. He married Elizabeth Preston at Christmas 1629, by whom he had 10 children, with three sons and two daughters surviving to adulthood. He was brought to Ireland by Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl of Strafford, as head of government in Ireland in 1633. He commanded the Royalist forces in Ireland from 1641 and became Lord Lieutenant of Ireland on the Restoration of Charles II in 1660. He died at his estate of Kingston Lacey, Dorset, on 21 July 1688.

list.item: Barnard, 'Butler, James, First Duke of Ormond (1610–1688), Lord Lieutenant of Ireland', ODNB

noteGrp.note: William Cavendish (1593-1676), 1st Duke of Newcastle upon Tyne, was baptised on 16 December 1593, the (second but first surviving) son of Charles Cavendish and his second wife, Catherine. He married twice, first Elizabeth Howard by whom he had five children (three sons and two daughters) and, second, Margaret Lucas. A writer, courtier and royalist army officer, he led his battalion, the Whitecoats, under the Royalist forces of Prince Rupert at the battle of Marston Moor in 1644. He died at Welbeck Abbey on Christmas Day 1676.

list.item: Hulse, 'Cavendish, William, First Duke of Newcastle upon Tyne (Bap. 1593, d. 1676), Writer, Patron, and Royalist Army Officer', ODNB

noteGrp.note: Katherine Cholmondeley (d.1657) was the daughter of Sir John Stanhope, 1st Lord Harrington, and his second wife, Margaret. She married Lord Robert Cholmondeley c.1610. She died on 15 June 1657 without issue and was buried in the chancel of St Oswald’s, Malpas.

list.item: Morrill, 'Cholmondeley, Robert, Earl of Leinster (1584–1659), Royalist Landowner', ODNB

noteGrp.note: Robert Cholmondeley (1584-1659), 1st Earl of Leinster, was born on 26 June 1584 in Middlesex to Sir Hugh and Mary Cholmondeley. He inherited the largest landed estate in Cheshire after his father's death in 1601. He was educated at Queen's College Oxford, and married Katherine Stanhope c.1610. They had no children. He was MP for Cheshire in 1625 and a supporter of Charles I during the Civil War. He was made Earl of Leinster in 1646. He died on 2 October 1659 and was buried next to his late wife in the chancel of St Oswald’s, Malpas.

list.item: Morrill, 'Cholmondeley, Robert, Earl of Leinster (1584–1659), Royalist Landowner', ODNB

noteGrp.note: Ursula Cholmondeley was baptised on 13 March 1600 at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave, was the eldest daughter of Robert Thornton and his first wife, Dorothy; she was William Thornton's half-sister. She married Marmaduke Cholmondeley of Bransby, and they had a son and two daughters. She was still alive in November 1665 when William Thornton, on his way home from York to East Newton, stopped at Bransby Hall.

list.item: 'Pedigree of Cholmeley, of Brandsby Hall, and Cholmley, of Boynton, Whitby, and Howsham', in Foster, Pedigrees of Yorkshire, vol. 3. n.p.

noteGrp.note: Katherine Cholmondeley was the daughter of the Stapletons of Wighill; mother Mary and father Robert or Henry, born c. 1607. She married George Twisleton (died c.1635), and then married Henry Cholmondeley, MP for New Malton 1641-48. They had three children, two sons and a daughter. She was buried on 14 June 1672 at St. Oswald, King and Martyr, Oswaldkirk.

list.item: Helms and Naylor, 'Cholmley, Sir Henry (1609-66), of West Newton Grange, Yorks', HPO

noteGrp.note: John Clotworthy, 1st Viscount Massereene, was son of Sir Hugh and Mary Clotworthy of Antrim. He was knighted in 1626 and married Margaret Jones, daughter of Viscount Ranelagh. They had one daughter. He was an Anglo-Irish politician, a presbyterian and an opponent of Thomas Wentworth during his time as Lord Deputy of Ireland. He died in September 1665.

list.item: Kelsey, 'Clotworthy, John, First Viscount Massereene (d. 1665), Politician', ODNB

noteGrp.note: Thomas Comber (1645-99) was the son of James and Mary Comber of Westerham, Kent, born on 19 March 1645 and baptised on 23 March at the parish church. From a royalist family, he was educated at Westerham school before entering Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge in 1659. He graduated with his BA in 1663 and became curate at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave at the behest of the absentee incumbent, Gilbert Bennett. He was ordained priest in September 1664 and in March 1665 he lodged with the Thorntons at East Newton for a year. After a further year of studies in Cambridge for an MA, he returned north. He married Alice Thornton’s eldest daughter, Alice, in November 1668 and in 1669 he was made rector of Holy Trinity, Stonegrave. They had nine children, with two sons and two daughters surviving him. Comber wrote several treatises and books on religious topics. He became prebendary of York in 1677, precentor at York in 1683, and Dean of Durham in 1691. He was made chaplain-in-ordinary to the joint monarchs William and Mary in 1692. He died of consumption on 25 November 1699 at East Newton and was buried at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave on 30 November.

list.item: Coleby, 'Comber, Thomas (1645–1699), Dean of Durham and Liturgist', ODNB

noteGrp.note: Mary Cotes was probably a servant in Alice Thornton's household in the mid-1660s. We have not been able to trace her further.

Roger Covill was a barrister based at Fremington, Swaledale, the son and heir of John Covill, a gentleman of Lockthwaite, Westmoreland. He was admitted to the Inner Temple in September 1630 and called to the bar in May 1639. He married Anne Norton, a relation of Alice Thornton’s, at Scruton on 17 June 1641. Thornton referred to him as her ‘cousin Covill’. They had two daughters. He drafted a deed at Alice Thornton’s request in 1662. He was buried on 12 July 1664 at St. Andrew, Grinton; his will was proved in 1665.

list.item: 'Scruton: baptism, marriage and burial record 572-1728', PR/SCR 1/1, NYCRO

noteGrp.note: John Crathorne was born c.1642, the son of Ralph Crathorne and his second wife, Margaret; William Thornton's nephew.

Margaret Crathorne was the daughter of Robert Thornton and his first wife Dorothy, baptised 9 May 1608 at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave. She was William Thornton's half-sister. Around 1632 she became the second wife of Ralph Crathorne of Crathorne, and they had a daughter and three sons. We do not know when she died.

Ralph Crathorne was born c.1634, the first son of Ralph Crathorne of Crathorne and his second wife, Margaret; William Thornton's nephew. He married Anne Tunstall, and they had three sons. We do not know when he died.

Oliver Cromwell (1599-1658), was Lord Protector of England, Wales and Ireland during the Interregnum period of 1649 until his death in 1658. Born 25 April 1599, the son of Robert and Elizabeth Cromwell, he was educated at Sidney Sussex College Cambridge and married Elizabeth Bourchier in 1621. They had nine children - five sons and four daughters. He died on 3 September 1658.

list.item: Morrill, 'Cromwell, Oliver (1599–1658), Lord Protector of England, Scotland, and Ireland', ODNB

noteGrp.note: Richard Cromwell (1626-1712), born 4 October 1626, was the third son, and fourth child, of Oliver and Elizabeth Cromwell. On his father's death in September 1658, he was elected Lord Protector of England, a position he held until 1659, when the Protectorate collapsed. He married Dorothy Maijor on 1 May 1649, and they had nine children, only four of whom survived to adulthood. He died on 12 July 1712.

list.item: Gaunt, 'Cromwell, Richard (1626–1712), Lord Protector of England, Scotland, and Ireland', ODNB

noteGrp.note: Robert Daggett of Howe was born c.1587. He studied at Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge, matriculated in 1605 and received his MA in 1612. He was ordained priest in 1613 and incorporated at Oxford in 1614. He was awarded his Bachelor of Divinity in 1619. He became Rector of Kirklington in April 1639. He died on 19 August 1644 and was buried at St. Michael, Kirklington.

Anne Danby (1630-1695) was the daughter of Mr John Culpeper. While we have not been able to confidently identify her father, in her Accompt written in 1683 Anne says that he was a royalist in England who had to flee to Virginia due to his support for the King, meaning Anne was born in England. However he cannot be Sir John Culpeper, identified by some as her father, because he died in 1660, and Anne says her father died before she was married in 1652. Anne also mentions being related to Lady Berkeley (Frances Culpeper Berkeley), wife to three colonial governors of Virginia. While in Virginia, c.1652, Anne married Christopher Danby, son of Katherine and Thomas Danby, becoming Alice Thornton's niece. Christopher's father did not approve of the match. Her first child born in Virginia in 1653 died straight after the birth. The couple relocated to Yorkshire and lived with Christopher's older brother and heir Thomas Danby at Farnley Hall, and had five more children, three sons and two daughters. It seems that Danby and her family lived with the Thorntons at East Newton at least twice in the 1660s: firstly in 1661 or 1662 for three months and later, after the death of Thomas Danby in 1667 and in the midst of continuing conflict between Anne and Thomas's widow, Margaret. In 1668, she was allegedly the source of rumours about Thomas Comber and Alice Thornton, resulting in her being evicted from the household by William Thornton. She died on 11 November 1695 and was buried at Holy Trinity Church, Micklegate, York.

list.item: Anne Danby's memorial in Holy Trinity, Micklegate (Pat Cullum photo)
Anne Danby, 'An Accompt', Cunliffe Lister Muniments [MIC 2281], NYCRO
' Philip Malory, Kequotan (Virginia), to Sir Thos Danby, 14 Feb 1653/4', NYCRO
Philip Mallory, Cecoughton (in Virginia), to Sir Thos Danby, 10 Jul 1653', NYCRO
Danby Pedigree in Whitaker, History of Richmondshire, vol. 2, between pp. 99-100

noteGrp.note: Alice Danby was born 22 May 1641 in Greenwich and baptised on 5 June at St Alfege's, Greenwich. She was the daughter of Thomas and Katherine Danby, making her Alice Thornton's niece. She possibly married William Hamilton at All Saints, Darton on 26 February 1656, age 15.

list.item: 'Dates of birth of the children of Sir Thos & Katherine Danby 1631-1645', ZS, NYCRO
'Darton, All Saints, Marriages 1647-1754', WDP62 1/1/2, West Yorkshire Archive Service, Wakefield

noteGrp.note: Francelia Parker was the daughter of Christopher and Anne Danby; Alice Thornton's great-niece. Although born in Leeds c.1659 and brought up in Yorkshire, she moved to colonial Virginia, where her parents had met, and married Joseph Goodrich in or around 1685. They had two sons before his death in 1694. She married Thomas Parker later that year. Her will was witnessed on 25 March 1699 in James City County, Virginia.

list.item: 'Will of Francelia Parker', in Cunliffe Lister Muniments [MIC 2281], NYCRO

noteGrp.note: Christopher Danby (1632-89) was the second son of Thomas and Katherine Danby, born 30 July 1632 at St-Martin-in-the-Fields, London; he was Alice Thornton's nephew. After his mother's death in 1645, the family emigrated to Virginia and around 1652 he married Anne Culpeper, against his father's wishes. Their first child, born in Virginia, died straight after birth. They moved back to Yorkshire and had five children, three sons and two daughters. On his older brother’s death in 1667, he became heir to his father's estate, but granted this estate to his son Abstrupus in the same year, as he was thought incapable of running it. He was buried on 25 November 1689 at St Mary’s, Masham.

list.item: 'Dates of birth of the children of Sir Thos & Katherine Danby 1631-1645', ZS, NYCRO
'Masham parish registers: baptisms, marriages and burials', PR/MAS 1/1, NYCRO

noteGrp.note: Charles Danby (1643-72) was the son of Thomas and Katherine Danby, born on 2 June 1643 at Snape; he was Alice Thornton's nephew. He matriculated at Gonville and Caius, Cambridge, in 1661 and was admitted to Gray's Inn in January 1664. He died without issue in April 1672.

list.item: 'Dates of birth of the children of Sir Thos & Katherine Danby 1631-1645', ZS, NYCRO

noteGrp.note: Francis Danby (1640-45) was born on 22 March 1640 at Farnley, the son of Thomas and Katherine Danby; he was Alice Thornton's nephew. He died in July 1645 and was buried at St Michael the Archangel, Well, Bedale. Thomas and Katherine's youngest son, born August 1645, was named after him.

list.item: 'Dates of birth of the children of Sir Thos & Katherine Danby 1631-1645', ZS, NYCRO
'An old memorandum book of Mr John Gale's', ZS, NYCRO

noteGrp.note: Margaret Danby (c.1640-88) was the daughter of William and Margaret Eure of Ingleby. She married Thomas Danby, son and heir of Thomas and Katherine Danby of Thorpe Perrow, in 1659; this made her Alice Thornton's niece by marriage. They had three children, a son and two daughters. She was widowed by the murder of her husband near Gray's Inn in August 1667, later rumoured to perhaps be at her instigation. She spent much of her widowhood in conflict with other members of the Danby family over her husband's estate. She died on 23 June 1688.

list.item: 'Margaret Eure to Thomas Danby, Whitsondin, 17 Dec 1658', [MIC 1560/208], NYCRO

noteGrp.note: Sir Thomas Danby (1610-60) was the son of Christopher and Frances Danby of Farnley, baptised 8 August 1610 at St. Mary’s, Masham. A ward of Christopher Wandesford after his father's death in 1624 and a protracted legal dispute, he entered St John's College, Cambridge in 1627. He married Christopher Wandesford’s daughter, Katherine, in 1630, making him Alice Thornton's brother-in-law. He was knighted in 1633, became Sheriff of York in 1637 and was elected MP for Richmond in 1640. He was banned from sitting in Parliament after 1642 and was fined heavily for his loyalty to Charles I. He and Katherine had 10 live-born children, seven of whom survived to adulthood. After his wife's death in 1645, he relocated to Virginia where he held lands, moving back to Yorkshire in the 1650s. He died in London on 5 August 1660 and was buried in the north aisle of the choir at York Minster.

list.item: 'Dates of birth of the children of Sir Thos & Katherine Danby 1631-1645', ZS, NYCRO
'Masham parish registers: baptisms, marriages and burials', PR/MAS 1/1, NYCRO

noteGrp.note: Thomas Danby (1631-67) was born on 17 August 1631 in Westminster, the oldest son and heir of Sir Thomas and Katherine Danby; he was Alice Thornton's nephew. He married Margaret Eure in 1658 and they had three children, a son and two daughters. In 1661 he became the first Mayor of Leeds. He was also briefly MP for Malton in 1661. He was killed in a tavern near Gray's Inn, London, on 31 July 1667. William Berridge, Thomas Jenney and John Ogle were accused of his murder but there were later rumours that his wife was involved in his death.

list.item: 'Dates of birth of the children of Sir Thos & Katherine Danby 1631-1645', ZS, NYCRO
Bolton and Watson, 'Danby, Thomas (1631-67), of Farnley, Yorks.', HPO

noteGrp.note: Conyers Darcy (1622-92), 2nd Earl Holdernesse, baptised 3 March 1622 at St Michael le Belfrey, York, was the son and heir of Conyers and Grace Darcy. Educated at University College, Oxford (1637), he entered Gray's Inn in 1640. He married four times: to Catherine Fane, Frances Howard, Frances Seymour and Elizabeth Frescheville. With Frances Howard he had six children, three sons and three daughters. He was elected MP for Boroughbridge in 1660, and became a peer in 1680, as Baron Conyers. He died at Aston on 13 December 1692.
