Henning, History of Parliament vol. 2 pp. 190-1

noteGrp.note: Dorothy Darcy (1572-1653) was the daughter of Henry and Ursula Belasyse. She married Conyers Darcy, 4th Lord Conyers, on 2 May 1594 at Coxwold, with whom she had 12 children, six sons and six daughters. She died on 11 May 1653 in Hornby.

list.item: Collins, Peerage of England vol. 2, part 1 (1735) p. 422
Lloyd, Parish registers of Coxwold, 1583-1666, p. 19

noteGrp.note: Henry Darcy (1610-62) was the third son of Conyers and Dorothy Darcy, baptised 19 October 1610 at Hornby. He married Mary Scrope in 1628 and they had 10 children. He died on 28 April 1662 and was buried at St Olave's, York.

list.item: Nichols, The Topographer and Genealogist vol. 3 p. 327

noteGrp.note: James Darcy was the sixth son of Conyers and Dorothy Darcy, born August 1617. He married Isabel Wyvill, and they had seven children, three sons and four daughters. He was elected MP for Richmond in 1660 but was not re-elected in 1661, being then appointed to Master of the Royal Stud. He died after 13 October 1673, when his will is dated.

list.item: M. W. Helms, P. A. Bolton, and Paula Watson, “DARCY, Hon. James (1617-73), of Sedbury Park, Nr. Richmond, Yorks.,” in History of Parliament Online, accessed January 15, 2023, http://www.histparl.ac.uk/volume/1660-1690/member/darcy-hon-james-1617-73.

noteGrp.note: Francis Darley (1605-79) was the son Sir Richard Darley of Buttercrambe, Yorkshire and his second wife, Elizabeth, born 1605; he was William Thornton's uncle via his sister Elizabeth. He was one of the executors of Alice Wandesford’s will in 1659. He is possibly the Francis Darley of Awdby given land in 1665, mentioned in William Thornton’s settlement of his daughters made 19 September 1667. He was buried at Buttercrambe on 31 December 1679.

list.item: Parish Register of Buttercrambe, 1665-1763, Borthwick Institute for Archives, PR BUT 2, p. 22
Settlement of William Thornton, 19 September 1667. Durham Cathedral Library CCOM 84

noteGrp.note: Richard Darley was the third son of Sir Richard and Elizabeth Darley of Buttercrambe, Yorkshire, born c. 1602. He was William Thornton's uncle, a younger brother of his mother Elizabeth. He married Elizabeth Hildyard, the niece of Catherine Hansby (Alice Thornton's great-grandmother), on 20 December 1632 at Bishop-Wilton, York. Elizabeth and Richard had six children, five sons and a daughter. He sat on the committee at York that dealt with sequestration, and via a deal with Thornton's uncle, William Wandesford, he was able to regain the family estate at Kirklington for her brother George Wandesford. After Wandesford’s death Alice married his nephew William Thornton. He died on 2 February 1681 and was buried at Bishop Wilton.

list.item: Anselment, First Booke, pp. xxii, 242 n302
York, Borthwick Institute. Parish registers for Bishop-Wilton, 1613-1901 PR/B/W 5, 9, 16-17

noteGrp.note: Don de Lan was a French page in the service of Robert Meredith, Chancellor of the Irish Exchequer, in the 1630s. We have not been able to trace him further.

Elizabeth Denton (1622-1669) was the first child of Robert Thornton and his second wife Elizabeth, baptised 24 September 1622 at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave; she was Alice Thornton's sister-in-law. She married John Denton, minister of Oswaldkirk, on 8 May 1654 at East Newton. They had at least two sons. She was buried on 14 February 1669.

list.item: NYCCRO, Holy Trinity, Stonegrave: Baptisms, Marriages & Burials 1584-1750 PR/STV 1/1

noteGrp.note: John Denton (1625-1709) was baptised on 2 February 1625 at St. Andrew’s Church, Kildwick-in-Craven, the son of John and Elizabeth Denton of Steeton. He studied at Clare College Cambridge, gaining his MA in 1653. He became minister of Oswaldkirk in 1654. In the same year, he married Elizabeth Thornton, older sister of William Thornton. He was ejected from Oswaldkirk in 1662 for nonconformity, after which he served as curate at Holy Trinity, Holy Trinity, Stonegrave, under Thomas Comber. Elizabeth died in 1669 and Denton remarried. His second wife, also named Elizabeth, died in 1715. With his first wife he had one or two sons, and with his second wife he had two sons and two daughters. He died on 14 January 1709 and was buried on 16 January in the north aisle of Holy Trinity, Stonegrave.

list.item: Robert Harrison and Andrew J. Hopper, “Denton, John (c. 1626–1709), Church of England Clergyman,” September 23, 2004, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/7516.
Brigg, The Parish Registers of Kildwick-in-Craven (1916) vol. 2 p. 5

noteGrp.note: John Denton was the son of John and Elizabeth Denton, baptised on 5 September 1655 at Oswaldkirk; he was William Thornton's nephew. He attended Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge, where he received his BA in 1677. We do not know when he died.
William Denton was probably the son of John and Elizabeth Denton; he was Alice and William Thornton's nephew. We have not been able to trace him further.

Sir James Dillon was the youngest son of Theobald and Eleanor Dillon, born c. 1600. An army officer, he became Commissioner of Ireland in 1627. He was elected MP for Co. Westmeath in 1634. Commissioned by Charles I in 1640 to recruit regiments from disbanded soldiers in Ireland, he was said to have been involved in the 1641 plot to seize Dublin castle. He married twice, first Elizabeth Plunkett in the 1630s, with whom he had two sons. Elizabeth died before 1653. His second marriage, in the early 1660s, was to Mary Ridge, a widow. He was still alive in 1669.

list.item: Elaine Murphy, “Dillon, Sir James,” in Dictionary of Irish Biography, accessed January 15, 2023, https://www.dib.ie/biography/dillon-sir-james-a2601.

noteGrp.note: John Dodsworth of Thornton Watlass (1597-1670) was the son of John and Winifred Dodsworth, baptised on 21 September 1597 at St. Gregory’s Church, Bedale. He matriculated Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge on 23 January 1613 and was admitted to Gray’s Inn on 24 March 1624. He married Frances Hutton, and they had five children, three sons and two daughters. He was buried at St. Mary’s Church, Thornton Watlass on 20 June 1670.

list.item: NYCRO, Thornton Watlass parish registers: baptisms, marriages and burials 1653-1696 PR/TW 1/2
NYCRO, Bedale Parish Records PR/BED 1/1 p. 69

noteGrp.note: Mr Edrington was a clergyman active in North Yorkshire in the late 1650s. He may be the vicar of Langton who graduated from St John's Cambridge in 1644; or a William Etherington who was instituted at St Agatha's, Gilling, in 1665.

list.item: Whitaker, History of Richmondshire vol. 1 p. 71

noteGrp.note: Katherine Farrer was a friend of Anne Danby, whom Anne tried to set up with Thomas Comber. Anne Danby's letter to Parson Farrer, mentioned in Alice's books, indicates that Katherine was a relation of his. We have not been able to identify her further.

list.item: NYCCRO, Letter from Anne Danby to Parson Farrer MIC 2281

noteGrp.note: George Farrer was probably the minister of Thornton Watlass, made rector of St Mary the Virgin in 1635. He may have studied at Alban Hall, Oxford in 1625 or he may have studied at Cambridge. Jackson suggests he may have been a chaplain at the Malton household of the Eure family.

Edward Fleetwood was the son of Thomas Fleetwood and his second wife, Bridget, born c. 1534. He was the brother of Alice Thornton's maternal grandmother, Joyce Osborne. He studied at St Alban Hall, Oxford (MA 1575), and married Christian Wentworth. The couple had at least four children. He was instituted rector of Wigan in 1571, a position he held until his death on 12 October 1604.

list.item: Bridgeman, History of the Church & Manor of Wigan p. 93

noteGrp.note: Sir Miles Fleetwood of Aldwinkle (1576-1641) was baptised on 1 October 1576. Thornton confuses him here with her maternal great-grandfather, Thomas Fleetwood, although he was related to her via her maternal grandmother Joyce - her brother William Fleetwood was Miles’s father. He married Anne Luke and they had four sons and four daughters. He was MP in several constituencies across England in the 1620s and 1630s, and was elected MP for Hindon, Wiltshire, in the Short Parliament of 1640, which he held until his death on 8 March 1641.

list.item: Alan Davidson and Rosemary Sgroi, “FLEETWOOD, Sir Miles (1576-1641), of Wood Street, London and Aldwinkle All Saints, Northants.,” in History of Parliament Online, accessed January 15, 2023, https://www.historyofparliamentonline.org/volume/1604-1629/member/fleetwood-sir-miles-1576-1641.

noteGrp.note: Jane Flouer was a servant in Alice Wandesford’s household at Hipswell in the 1650s. We have not been able to trace her further.

John Frescheville (1606-82), first Baron Frescheville, was the son of Sir Peter Frescheville and his first wife, Joyce, born 1606. He was Alice Thornton's uncle, the younger half-brother of her mother, Alice Wandesford. He was educated at Magdalen Hall Oxford and the Middle Temple (1624). He married twice; firstly Bruce Nicholls, who died in 1629 without issue, and then Sarah Harington with whom he had three daughters. He was elected MP for Derbyshire in 1628, though a year later Charles I abolished parliament. He was Lieutenant of Derbyshire from 1630-42, and then became a Captain in the Royalist army. He was executor of his half-sister Alice Wandesford’s will in 1659, and was mentioned in William Thornton’s settlement of his daughters in 1667. He was created Baron in 1665 and died without a male heir to inherit his baronetcy on 31 March 1682.

list.item: Gladwyn Turbutt, “Frescheville [Frecheville] Family (per. 1518–1682), Gentry,” January 3, 2008, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/71872.
Settlement of William Thornton, 19 September 1667. Durham Cathedral Library CCOM 84

noteGrp.note: Sir Peter Frescheville (1575-1634) was the eldest son of Peter Frescheville of Staveley and his second wife, Margaret, baptised 14 March 1575. He sat in the House of Commons as MP for Derbyshire in 1601 and in 1621-22. He built Staveley Hall in 1604. He married twice, first Joyce Osborne (née Fleetwood), widow of Hewett Osborne, with whom he had three children (a son and two daughters) and secondly Isabel Neville who died without issue. His marriage to Joyce made him Alice Thornton's maternal step-grandfather. He died on 9 April 1634 and was buried at Staveley.

Susanna Graham (1618-99) was the daughter of William and Anne Washington, baptised 15 November 1618 at St-Martin-in-the-Fields, London. She married Ranald Graham of Lewisham c.1640. The couple purchased Nunnington Hall in Ryedale in 1655 and Ranald became Justice of the Peace of the North Riding of Yorkshire in 1662. This brought Susanna into the social circle of Alice Thornton, who counted her as a friend. She was godmother to Thornton's youngest daughter and eighth child Joyce, born in 1665. She died on 26 February 1699 and was buried in the parish church at Lewisham.

list.item: Edward Rowlands, “GRAHME, Ranald (c.1605-85), of Petty France, Westminster and Nunnington, Wath, Yorks.,” in History of Parliament Online, accessed January 15, 2023, http://www.histparl.ac.uk/volume/1660-1690/member/grahme-ranald-1605-85.
The Writings of George Washington, vol. XIV pp. 365-6
Mason and Kitto, Register of Baptisms, Marriages, and Burials in the Parish of St. Martin in the Fields vol. 2 p. 54

noteGrp.note: Joseph Hall (1574-1656) was the son of John and Winifred Hall, born on 1 July 1574 at Bristow Park, Ashby-de-la-Zouch. He was a religious writer, satirist, and became Bishop of Exeter (1627) and Norwich (1647). He married Elizabeth Winniff in 1603 with whom he had eight children, six sons and two daughters. He died on 8 September 1656.

list.item: Richard A. McCabe, “Hall, Joseph (1574–1656), Bishop of Norwich, Religious Writer, and Satirist,” January 3, 2008, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/11976

noteGrp.note: Mr Hubert was a man in the Dublin area in the 1630s who had been helped by Christopher Wandesford in a legal case. We have not been able to trace him further.

Anne Hutton may be the daughter of Thomas Wentworth's sister, Margaret, and her husband, Richard Hutton. Thornton describes her as a 'cousin', a kinship that could be claimed via great-great-grandfather George Bowes, to whom both the Wandesfords and Huttons were related. We have not been able to trace her further.

list.item: Foster, Pedigrees of the County Families of Yorkshire 3 n.p.
Raine, Correspondence of Dr. Matthew Hutton, Archbishop of York, p. 317

noteGrp.note: Captain Robert Innes, a Scottish soldier, served as quartermaster in the Earl of Leven’s Horse Regiment, commanded by Leven’s son, Alexander Leslie Lord Balgonie, in 1644. The major of this regiment was Sir Robert Adair of Kinhilt. He fought at the battle of Marston Moor in July 1644, after which his regiment was stationed at Alice Wandesford’s property, Hipswell Hall. According to Thornton, Innes plotted to abduct her after she had refused his hand in marriage, but one of his men whom she had previously helped with an injured hand warned her of the plot. Innes was still serving under Leven in 1646.

list.item: Furgol, A Regimental History of the Covenanting Armies, 1639-1651 (Edinburgh, 1990)
Terry, Papers relating to the Army of the Solemn League and Covenant, 1643-1647 (Scottish History Society, Edinburgh, 1917), vol. 1 pp. lv, 132, 247

noteGrp.note: Ralph Janson of Thorpe was a friend or servant of Alice Thornton's in the early 1650s. We have not been able to trace him further, although a Ralph Janson of Newton-le-Willows, Richmondshire, petitioned for a soldier's pension in 1670, so he may have fought in the Wars of the Three Kingdoms.
Thomas Jenney was implicated in the murder of Alice Thornton's nephew, Thomas Danby, in London, July 1667 but was pardoned and released from jail in October 1667.

list.item: Calendar of State Papers, Domestic Series, of the Reign of Charles II: 1660-[1685], vol. 7 Issue 1667

noteGrp.note: John Lambert (1619-84) was born on 7 September 1619 to Josias Lambert and his second or third wife, Anne. He was a Parliamentarian general during the Wars of the Three Kingdoms. He married Frances Lister on 10 September 1639, and they had 10 children, three of whom survived to adulthood. He died on 1 March 1684.

list.item: D. N. Farr, “Lambert [Lambart], John (Bap. 1619, d. 1684), Parliamentary Soldier and Politician,” January 8, 2015, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/15939

noteGrp.note: Edward or Edmund Lassells was a coffin-bearer at the funeral of William Thornton in September 1668. Alice Thornton describes him as a cousin; her paternal great-aunt, Eleanor Wandesford, had married George Lassells and this Edward/Edmund may have been a descendant of theirs. Perhaps he is the Edward Lassells who was buried on 22 August 1675 at St Michael-le-Belfrey, York.

William Laud (1573-1645), Archbishop of Canterbury, was born on born on 7 October 1573 in Reading to William and Lucy Laud. He was educated at Reading school and then Oxford University and elected Archbishop of Canterbury in 1633. A royalist, he was executed on 10 January 1645.

list.item: Anthony Milton, “Laud, William (1573–1645), Archbishop of Canterbury,” May 21, 2009, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/16112

noteGrp.note: Richard Legard was the second son of John and Elizabeth Legard, baptised at Ganton on 15 March 1607. He was related to Alice Thornton via Alice's great-great-grandfather, George Bowes, who married Dorothy Mallory. A barrister at the Middle Temple, he was admitted to Gray's Inn on 14 March 1625. He married Elizabeth, the daughter or widow of John Pierson of Mowthorpe on 14 August 1666 at Nunburnholme but had no children. He was a Royalist captain during the Wars of the Three Kingdoms and was godfather to Alice Thornton's eighth child and youngest daughter, Joyce, in September 1665. He died around 1680 (when his will was witnessed).

list.item: Simon Healy, “LEGARD, John (1576-1643), of Ganton, Yorks.,” in History of Parliament Online, accessed January 15, 2023, http://www.histparl.ac.uk/volume/1604-1629/member/legard-john-1576-1643.
York, Borthwick Institute of Archives Parish Registers of Nunburnholme GB 193 PR/NUN

noteGrp.note: David Leslie, 1st Lord Newark (1601-82), the son of Patrick and Jean Leslie, was an army officer in the employ of Alexander Leslie, 1st Earl Leven. A key figure in the parliamentarian success at the battle of Marston Moor in July 1644 as Major-General of the Horse for his regiment, he was stationed in Yorkshire. He married Jane Yorke and they had nine children; three sons and six daughters. He was elevated to the title of 1st Lord Newark by Charles II. He died in February 1682.

list.item: T. F. Henderson and Edward M. Furgol, “Leslie, David, First Lord Newark (1601–1682), Army Officer,” October 8, 2009, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/16486.
Terry, Papers relating to the Army of the Solemn League and Covenant, 1643-1647 (Scottish History Society, Edinburgh, 1917), vol. 1 p. xxiv

noteGrp.note: George Lightfoot was a servant in the household of Alice Wandesford in the 1650s. He married another of the household servants, Daphne Cassell, before 1654, and they had at least one child, a daughter. A literate man, he and Daphne were witnesses to Alice Wandesford's will in 1659. It seems likely that after her death, the Lightfoots entered the Thorntons’ service as there are indications of them working at East Newton after 1668, and then going into the service of the Combers. George and his wife might still have been working at East Newton Hall in 1682 when he is mentioned in a letter from Thomas Comber to his mother-in-law. We do not know when he died.

list.item: 'The Will of Dame Alice Wandesford', in McCall, Wandesforde Family, pp. 357-58

noteGrp.note: Anne Barrett was the daughter of Robert and Eleanor Loftus, and the granddaughter of Adam Loftus, Lord Chancellor of Ireland, born c. 1626. She and her parents lived in the household of Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl Strafford, at Dublin in the late 1630s, when she kept company with a young Alice and Wentworth's daughters Anne and Arabella. She married Richard (Lennard) Barrett c.1653 and had four children, two sons and two daughters. She died on 4 April 1659.

Edward Loftus, 2nd Viscount Elye was the second son of Adam and Sarah Loftus, born c.1598. His father was Lord Chancellor of Ireland. He married Jane Lindley and through her inherited Middleham Castle, Yorkshire, where Alice Thornton's sister, Katherine Danby, gave birth to her penultimate child in August 1644. The Loftus, Wentworth and Wandesford families were close associates in Ireland. Edward and Jane had two children, a son and a daughter. He died on 11 April 1680.

Robert Loftus of Waithwith was possibly born in 1614 at St Mary’s, Richmond to William Loftus. A servant of Alice Wandesford, he was present at the wedding of Alice and William Thornton in 1651 and is mentioned in Alice Wandesford’s will of 1659 (but could not sign his name), in which he was named as her servant. He had four daughters and a son. He may have been the local man to whom the Thorpe Edge lead mine in Swaledale was leased in 1656 along with Robert Barker and some Derbyshire investors. His will, dated 29 August 1672, shows that he owed money to Christopher Wandesford, Alice Thornton's brother. He was buried at St Michael and All Angels, Hudswell, North Yorkshire.

list.item: “Robert Loftus Waitewith 1672,” Yorkshire Dales History (blog), accessed January 15, 2023, https://yorkshiredaleshistory.files.wordpress.com/2021/03/57-121-robert-loftus-waitewith-1672.pdf.
'The Will of Dame Alice Wandesford' in McCall, Wandesforde pp. 357-58

noteGrp.note: William Lowcock was rector of All Saints, Nunnington from 1658 until his death in 1678. He married Helen Bentley of Pannal on 10 October 1661 at Nunnington and they had two daughters and two sons. He baptised Alice Thornton's son, Robert, in 1662 at the family home, East Newton Hall. He died on 31 July 1678.

Connor Maguire (1616-45), 2nd Baron Enniskillen, was the eldest son of Brian Roe and Rose Maguire. He attended Oxford University but did not graduate. On his father's death in 1632, he became 2nd Baron Enniskillen. He married Mary Fleming, and they had one son. As a member of the House of Lords in Ireland, he was one of the conspirators in the failed plot to seize Dublin Castle during the Irish rebellion of 1641 and was imprisoned in the Tower of London. He escaped for five weeks in 1644, but was recaptured, stood trial and executed at Tyburn on 20 February 1645.

list.item: Brian Mac Cuarta, “Maguire, Connor [Cornelius], Second Baron of Enniskillen (c. 1612–1645), Conspirator,” January 3, 2008, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/17790.
Emmett O’Byrne, “Maguire, Conor,” in Dictionary of Irish Biography, accessed January 15, 2023, https://www.dib.ie/biography/maguire-conor-a5376.

noteGrp.note: Hugh Óg MacMahon was a younger son of Brian Hugh Óg MacMahon and his wife Mary, born in 1606 or 1607. He was an Irish conspirator in the failed 1641 plot to seize Dublin Castle during the Irish Rebellion and it was his drunken confession to his Protestant foster brother, Owen Connolly, that brought down the plot. He was imprisoned in the Tower of London, along with co-conspirator Conor Maguire. They escaped for five months in August 1644 but were captured. He was put on trial on 13 November 1644 and executed at Tyburn on 22 November.

list.item: Pádraig Lenihan, “Mac Mahon [MacMahon], Hugh Oge (1606/7–1644), Conspirator,” September 23, 2004, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/17686.
Micheál Ó Siochrú, “MacMahon, Hugh Óg,” in Dictionary of Irish Biography, accessed January 15, 2023, https://www.dib.ie/biography/macmahon-hugh-og-a5257.

noteGrp.note: Edmund Mainwaring was the second son of Randle and Margaret Mainwaring of Over Peover, Cheshire, born in 1579. He matriculated at Brasenose College, Oxford in 1594 and All Souls in 1600. He married a woman called Jane, and they had three children, a daughter and two sons, who were baptised at York. A civil lawyer, he held various positions before becoming Chancellor of Chester in 1634. He died c.1643.

list.item: Sheila Doyle, “Mainwaring, Edmund (b. 1579, d. in or after 1643), Civil Lawyer,” September 23, 2004, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/70467.

noteGrp.note: Jane Mainwaring was the wife of Edmund Mainwaring. Her birth name is unknown, but she is thought to have come from York. She and Edmund married before 1614 had three children, a daughter and two sons.

Captain Mainwaring could be William Mainwaring, son of Edmund Mainwaring, killed during the Siege of Chester in 1645; or Philip Mainwaring, son of Randle and Jane Mainwaring (d.1647), who is referred to as a 'captaine of the horse'. Both were involved in the defence of Chester.

list.item: Finley, A Short History of the Mainwaring Family, p. 86
Ormerod, The History of the County Palatine and City of Chester 1, pp. 483, 485

noteGrp.note: Robert Meredith was the son of Richard and Sarah Meredith, born c.1597. His father was Bishop of Leighlin. He married Anne Usher and they had three sons. He served as Chancellor of the Exchequer of Ireland from 1634 until his death. He held a Greenhills estate in Kildare. He died on 17 October 1668 and was buried in the family vault at St Patrick's Cathedral, Dublin.
Margery Millbanke was a servant in the Thornton's household in 1667. We have not been able to trace her further.

George Monck (1608-70), born 6 December 1608 at Great Potheridge, Devon, was the fourth son of Sir Thomas Monck, a landowner in Devon, and his wife, Elizabeth. He volunteered in the English expedition against Cadiz in 1625, which was the beginning of a very successful military career. A colonel in the Royalist army, he landed in Dublin in 1642 to quell the Irish uprising. He married Anne Clarges in 1653 and they had one son. He died on 1 January 1670.

list.item: Terry Clavin, “Monck, George,” in Dictionary of Irish Biography, accessed January 15, 2023, https://www.dib.ie/biography/monck-george-a5885.
Ronald Hutton, “Monck [Monk], George, First Duke of Albemarle (1608–1670), Army Officer and Naval Officer,” December 9, 2021, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/18939.

noteGrp.note: Philip Nesbit was the son of Philip and Elizabeth Nesbit of York. He received his Cambridge BA and MA from Corpus Christi in 1638 and 1641 and held the rectorship of Kirklington from 1649-62. He married Susan Hemmingway and they had six children, four sons and two daughters, five of whom survived childhood. He was removed from the rectorship of Kirklington in 1662 for refusing to subscribe to the Act of Uniformity. He died the next year and was buried at St Martins, York on 15 October 1663.

Robert Nettleton was a creditor of Christopher Wandesford, Alice Thornton's father. William Thornton inherited this debt via his marriage to Alice. Possibly Robert Nettleton of Thornhill Lees who died in 1673.

Christopher Norton was the third son of Maulger and Alice Thornton's maternal aunt Anne Norton; Alice Thornton's first cousin. He was still alive in 1685 when he sold the family home of St Nicholas, Richmond. He had a daughter, Anne.

William Norton (1625-66), baptised on 2 July 1625 at Manfield, was the son of Maulger and Anne Norton; he was Alice Thornton's first cousin. He was admitted to Gray's Inn on 2 September 1649 and was murdered in December 1666 in London.

list.item: Anselment, First Booke, p. 257 n495, p. 267 n623
Register of Admissions to Gray's Inn, p. 251
Stavert, The Parish Register of Manfield p. 6

noteGrp.note: John Ogle was implicated in the murder of Alice Thornton's nephew, Thomas Danby, in London in 1667 but was pardoned and released from jail in October 1667.

list.item: Calendar of State Papers, Domestic Series, of the Reign of Charles II: 1660-[1685], Vol. 7, Issue 1667, p. 520.

noteGrp.note: Anne Osborne was the daughter of Thomas Walmesley of Dunkenhalgh and his first wife, Eleanor. She married William Middleton and they had no children. On his death, she married (before 1630) Edward Osborne, Alice Thornton's maternal uncle, and became his second wife. They had a son, Thomas. She was buried on 20 August 1666 at Harthill.

Sir Hewett Osborne (1567-1599) was baptised on 13 March 1567, the son of Sir Edward and Anna Osborne; he was Alice Thornton's maternal grandfather. A landowner and soldier, he married Joyce Fleetwood and they had a son and a daughter. He owned lands at Kiveton, Yorkshire, but lived in Essex. He died in September 1599.

list.item: Waters, Genealogical memoirs of the extinct family of Chester of Chicheley vol. 1, pp. 231-32.

noteGrp.note: Joyce Frescheville, born 1569, was the daughter of Sir Thomas Fleetwood of the Vache and his second wife, Bridget; she was the maternal grandmother of Alice Thornton. She married Sir Hewett Osborne of Kiveton on 26 December 1588 and they had two children, Edward and Alice. Hewett died in 1599 and on 18 October 1604 she married Sir Peter Frescheville and they had 3 children. She died on 16 April 1619 and was buried at St John the Baptist, Staveley, Derbyshire.

list.item: Waters, Genealogical memoirs of the extinct family of Chester of Chicheley vol. 1, pp. 231-32

noteGrp.note: Christopher Parkes, born c.1642, attended St John's College Cambridge where he graduated with an MA in 1663. He was vicar of Catterick from 1660 and minister of the chapel at Hipswell, Bolton-super-Swale and Hudswell.

Sir John Payton (1561-1616) was the son of Robert and Elizabeth Payton. He married Alice Osborne, sister of Hewett Osborne, making him Alice Thornton's maternal great-uncle by marriage. John and Alice had six sons and seven daughters. He was twice elected MP for Cambridgeshire, in 1593 and in 1604, and died on 19 December 1616.

list.item: Andrew Thrush, “PEYTON, Sir John (c.1561-1616), of Peyton Hall, Isleham, Cambs.,” in History of Parliament Online, accessed January 15, 2023, http://www.historyofparliamentonline.org/volume/1604-1629/member/peyton-sir-john-1561-1616.

noteGrp.note: William Parsons was the son of James and Catherine Parsons, born c.1570. He became one of the Lord Justices of Ireland after the death of Alice Thornton's father, Christopher Wandesford, in 1640 until 1642. He had previously been Surveyor General of Ireland and an MP for County Wicklow. He married Elizabeth Lany and they had 12 children, five sons and seven daughters. He died in January or February 1650 and is buried at St Margaret's, Westminster.

list.item: Sean Kelsey, “Parsons, Sir William, Baronet (c. 1570–1650), Political Administrator and Promoter of the Plantation of Ireland,” September 23, 2004, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/21476.

noteGrp.note: John Plummer discovered the body of George Wandesford, Alice Thornton's brother, near Catterick Bridge on the river Swale in 1651. We have not been able to trace him further, although the name 'Plummer' is attested in Easby parish registers and wills from Richmond, Reeth and Bedale.

Frances Portington was the daughter of Robert and Elizabeth Thornton and was the youngest sister of Alice Thornton's husband, William. She became the third wife of Timothy Portington of Malton on 27 July 1663 and they had one son. She was buried at St Michael, New Malton on 11 March 1705.

list.item: NYCRO, Holy Trinity, Stonegrave: Baptisms, Marriages & Burials 1584-1750 PR/STV 1/1
York, Borthwick Institute of Archives, Parish Register of St. Michael, New Malton MIC 1148 - check

noteGrp.note: Timothy Portington was the son of Francis and Ellen Portington, born c.1630. An apothecary in New Malton, he was married three times; to Mary Pye (d.1654), Mary Ruddock (d.1662), and Frances Thornton; the younger sister of Alice Thornton's husband, William. He had a daughter with Mary Ruddock and a son with Frances. He died on 26 June 1697.

list.item: Anselment, First Booke, p. 265 n600, p. 266 n614

noteGrp.note: Mr Raines was a man to whom William Thornton was in debt, as well as his brother-in-law Timothy Portington. He could be John Raynes of Appleton-le-Street, west of Malton, who held the manor of Malton Priory until 1665, or Thomas Raynes, an attorney and Lord Mayor of York in the 1660s.

list.item: Foster, Pedigrees of the County Families of Yorkshire vol. 3, n.p.

noteGrp.note: Sir George Ratcliffe (1593-1657) was the son of Nicholas and Margaret Ratcliffe, baptised on 21 April 1593. He was educated at University College Oxford where he graduated in May 1612, having entered Gray's Inn in February 1612. He was called to the bar in 1618. He was briefly engaged to the only daughter of John Finch but she died age 10 in 1621. He married Anne Trappes at Thornhill, York on 21 February 1622. This made him a cousin-by-marriage of Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl Strafford, and George became part of Strafford's Irish administration 1633-40. He was imprisoned in Dublin Castle after being tried for treason in 1640. After his release in 1642 he spent much of his time in the Netherlands and died in 1657. George and Anne had a son.

list.item: Fiona Pogson, “Radcliffe, Sir George (Bap. 1593, d. 1657), Lawyer and Politician,” January 3, 2008, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/22980.
Louis A. Knafla, “Finch, John, Baron Finch of Fordwich (1584–1660), Speaker of the House of Commons and Judge,” January 3, 2008, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/9438.

noteGrp.note: Martha Richison was a witness at Alice and William Thornton's wedding in 1651. We have not been able to trace her further.
Jane Rimer was a midwife active in the Richmondshire area in the mid-1650s. We have not been able to trace her further.
Anne Robinson was a maid in the Thornton household in the early 1660s. We have not been able to trace her further.

Matthew Robinson (1628-94) was the third son of Thomas and Frances Robinson, baptised at Rokeby on 14 December 1628. He graduated from Cambridge in 1652 and was appointed vicar of St Lambert, Burneston in 1651, which he held for 40 years. He married Jane Pickering on 12 October 1657. They had no children. He died at Ripley on 27 November 1694 and was buried at Burneston.

list.item: G. Le G. Norgate, “Robinson, Matthew (1628–1694),” n.d., https://doi.org/10.1093/odnb/9780192683120.013.23859.

noteGrp.note: Mr Robinson was possibly Thomas Robinson of Easby, who held land in the Richmond area.

persName.roleName: Prince and count of the Palatinate, Duke of Cumberland

noteGrp.note: Prince Rupert of the Palatinate, Duke of Cumberland (1619-82) was born on 18 December 1619 to Frederick V of the Palatinate and Countess Louisa Juliana of Nassau. One of the main military commanders in the Wars of the Three Kingdoms, he never married, but had two children, a son with Francesca Bard, to whom his marriage has never been acknowledged (although a purported marriage certificate dated 1664 has been found), and a daughter with Margaret Hughes. He died on 29 November 1682.

list.item: Ian Roy, “Rupert, Prince and Count Palatine of the Rhine and Duke of Cumberland (1619–1682), Royalist Army and Naval Officer,” May 19, 2011, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/24281.

noteGrp.note: Anne Overton (1647-79), the daughter of Robert and Mabel Wake, was baptised 19 January 1647. She married James Savile, 2nd Earl of Sussex, and they had a son, James, who did not survive infancy. After her husband’s death in 1671, she married Fairfax Overton in April 1674. She died in 1679.

Laurence Sayer, son of Laurence and Elizabeth Sayer, was born c.1632. The Sayers were a recusant family in Worsall, Northallerton, whose estates had been forfeited in the 1650s when they were owned by Laurence Sayer senior. Laurence Sayer junior borrowed heavily to buy back the estates. He is possibly the same Laurence Sayer who married Catherine Burdon in 1690, who went on to have a son, Robert.

list.item: Clay, Yorkshire Royalist Composition Papers, p. 120

noteGrp.note: Richard Shuttleworth (1587-1699) was the son of Thomas and Anne Shuttleworth. In 1607 he inherited Gawthorpe Hall from his uncle, Lawrence Shuttleworth. He married Fleetwood Barton with whom he had 12 children, eight sons and four daughters. He may also have married Judith Thorpe. A Parliamentarian, he was MP for Preston from 1640-48 and was re-elected in 1654 during the Interregnum. He died in 1669.

list.item: Dugdale, Visitation of the County Palatine of Lancaster 1664-5 part 3 pp. 217-2
Abram, Parish of Blackburn pp. 105 onwards
Keeler and Elton, The Long Parliament pp. 338-39

noteGrp.note: Possibly Enoch Sinclair, rector of Slingsby, who was educated at St John's College Cambridge, graduating in 1633 and made curate of Auburn Chapel, Carnaby (East Riding) in 1635, a position he held until at least 1638.
Mary Smith was the daughter of Hugh and Elizabeth Smyth of Long Ashton, Somerset. She married Sir Thomas Smith of Hatherton, Cheshire. Thomas and Mary had 22 children. We do not know when she died.

list.item: Browne, Notitia Parliamentaria, part II pp. 229–239

noteGrp.note: Sir Thomas Smith was the son of Thomas and Anne Smith of Hatherton, Cheshire, born c.1595. Mayor of Chester from 1622 and High Sheriff of Cheshire in 1623, he sat as MP for Chester 1640-44 in the Short and then Long Parliaments before being barred from Parliament for his royalist support. He married Mary Smith and they had 22 children. He died c.1668.

list.item: Browne, Notitia Parliamentaria, part II pp. 229–239

noteGrp.note: Dr Smith was a physician active in the Richmondshire area in the late 1650s. We have not been able to trace him further.

Sir Hugh Smithson of Stanwick St. John, North Yorkshire, was the son of Anthony and Eleanor Smithson, born c.1598. He was a London merchant, recusant and royalist, made Baronet of Stanwick in 1660 by Charles II for his support. He married Dorothy Rawsthorne and they had four sons and two daughters. He died on 21 October 1670.

Sir Jeremy (later Jerome) Smithson (1632-84), 2nd Baronet Stanwick, was the eldest son and heir of Sir Hugh Smithson, 1st Baronet Stanwick, and his wife, Dorothy. In the late 1640s or very early 1650s he plotted to abduct Alice Thornton, but a man named Thomas Binks warned her of the plot and she was able to escape. He married Mary Wingate, and they had a son and a daughter. A deposition against Smithson for libel taken at York Castle in 1665 provides clear evidence that he changed his name from Jeremy to Jerome. He became 2nd Baronet Stanwick on his father's death in 1670 and died in 1684.

list.item: Raine, Depositions from the Castle of York, p. 131

noteGrp.note: Uncle Smithson is one of Sir Jerome's Smithson's paternal uncles, Francis, Richard or John. We are not able to identify him any more precisely.

Charles Stewart (1630-85), King Charles II of England, Scotland and Ireland, was born on 29 May 1630 to King Charles I and Henrietta Maria. He was King of Scotland 1649-51 and King of England, Scotland and Ireland from the Restoration of 1660 until his death in 1685. He married Catherine of Braganza but had no legitimate issue. He fathered at least twelve children out of wedlock by various mistresses. He died on 6 February 1685.

list.item: Paul Seaward, “Charles II (1630–1685), King of England, Scotland, and Ireland,” May 19, 2011, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/5144.

noteGrp.note: Mr Thomson was a man living at Catterick Bridge in the early 1650s. We have not been able to trace him further.

list.item: “91/58 Thomas Thomson Bolton on Swale 1562,” Yorkshire Dales History (blog), accessed January 15, 2023, https://yorkshiredaleshistory.files.wordpress.com/2021/12/91-58-thomas-thomson-bolton-on-swale-1562.pdf.

noteGrp.note: Christopher Thornton was the 9th child of Alice and William Thornton. He was born at East Newton, 11 November 1667 and baptized the next day at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave. He contracted smallpox and died on 1 December 1667. He was buried at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave the following day.

Joyce Thornton was the 8th child of Alice and William Thornton, born on 23 September 1665 at East Newton and baptized on 28 September at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave. She fell ill on 20 January 1666 with a cold and red spots and died on 26 January. She was buried the next day at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave.

list.item: NYCRO, Stonegrave: Baptisms, Marriages & Burials 1584-1750 PR/STV 1/1

noteGrp.note: Robert Thornton (1662-92) was the seventh child and third son of Alice and William Thornton. He was born on 19 September 1662 at East Newton and baptised the next day at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave. He was educated first by John Denton, then by the reverend John Burton at Sutton-on-the-Forest. He entered Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge in April 1680, before moving to University College, Oxford in May 1682. In 1687 he became the rector of Oddington but resigned it later that year. He was by now heavily in debt. In 1691 he was offered a living in Northamptonshire but swapped it for that of Boldon, diocese of Durham, and resided at the Deanery in Durham with his sister, Alice, and her husband, Thomas Comber. In 1692 Comber helped arrange a marriage for him, to a woman worth £2800, but he fell ill and died on 4 June 1692, aged 29. He is buried in the Chapel of the Nine Altars, Durham Cathedral.

list.item: TC Autobs, SS 156, pp. xxxviii, liii, lvii, 12, 25-6

noteGrp.note: Robert Thornton was the son of William and Eleanor Thornton of East Newton, born c.1575; he was William Thornton’s father. His first marriage was to Dorothy Metham and they had four daughters, one of whom died in infancy. He then married Elizabeth Darley, with whom he had seven children, four sons and three daughters. He was buried at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave on 27 May 1637.

list.item: NYCRO, Holy Trinity, Stonegrave: Baptisms, Marriages & Burials 1584-1750 PR/STV 1/1

noteGrp.note: Thomas Thornton (1626-85) was the son of Robert and Elizabeth Thornton, and the younger brother of William Thornton, baptised 29 August 1626 at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave. He was buried on 17 August 1685 at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave.

list.item: NYCRO, Holy Trinity, Stonegrave: Baptisms, Marriages & Burials 1584-1750 PR/STV 1/1

noteGrp.note: William Thornton (1660), the 6th child and 2nd son of Alice and William Thornton, was born and baptized at St Nicholas, Richmond, on 17 April 1660. He died on 28 April 1660 of smallpox and was buried the next day at Easby, in the same grave as Thornton’s first child, an unnamed girl.
Mr Tirrill of Hoddesdon was a chief mourner at the funeral of Alice Thornton's brother John Wandesford at Broxbourne, Hertfordshire in 1664. We have not been able to trace him further.

Barbara Todd was a maid of Anne Danby, Alice Thornton's niece-by-marriage, who lived in the Thornton household with her mistress in the 1660s. After leaving their household in 1668, after being implicated in spreading rumours about Thornton and Thomas Comber, she married John Pape on 29 May 1670 at Nunnington. They had at least one child. We have not been able to trace her further.

list.item: York, Borthwick Institute of Archives, Parish Registers of New Malton, St. Leonards PR/N/MAL/L/2

noteGrp.note: Young Mr Troutbeck was a man in the Richmondshire area in the mid-1650s and was an acquaintance of Lady Alice Wandesford, Thornton’s mother. We have not been able to trace him further.

Elizabeth I (1533-1603) was Queen of England from 1558 until her death in 1603. Born on 7 September 1533, she was the daughter of Henry VIII and his second wife, Anne Boleyn. She died on 24 March 1603.

list.item: Patrick Collinson, “Elizabeth I (1533–1603), Queen of England and Ireland,” January 5, 2012, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/8636.

noteGrp.note: Sir Christopher Wandesford was the son of Francis and Jane Wandesford of Kirklington born c.1548; he was Alice Thornton's great-grandfather. He married Elizabeth Bowes c.1568 and they had four children (three sons and a daughter). He was the Vice President of the Council of the North and was responsible for escorting Mary Queen of Scots from Carlisle to Bolton in 1568. He was buried at Kirklington on 11 July 1590.
Christopher Wandesford (1617-27) was the son of Christopher and Alice Wandesford; he was Alice Thornton's older brother. He died age 10 in 1627.

William Wandesford of Pickhill was the son of Richard and Muriel Wandesford and was a cousin of Alice Thornton's father, Christopher Wandesford. He married Elizabeth Ayscough on 27 October 1619 and by 1624 they had three sons. He was in Dublin in 1640 and was a witness to Christopher Wandesford's will. He was later an executor of Wandesford's estate.

Luke Wastell was the third son of Leonard and Anne Wastell of Scorton and Kirkby Knowle. He married twice; first Sarah Laton and then Elizabeth Allison (née Pattison). He was a Parliamentarian during the 1640s. He is possibly the Luke Wastell buried at Kirkby Fleetham on 16 February 1697.

list.item: NYCRO, Parish Registers for Kirby Fleetham 1591-1718. PR/KRF 1/1

noteGrp.note: Robert Webster was an acquaintance of Alice and William Thornton who lived in Nunnington in the 1650s and 1660s. He was buried at Nunnington on 27 October 1667.

list.item: NYCRO, Nunnington Baptisms, Marriages and Burials 1539-1837

noteGrp.note: Elizabeth Wentworth was the daughter of Godfrey and Anne Rhodes, born c.1614. She became the third wife of Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl Strafford, c.1632 and they had two children, Thomas and Margaret. She was also stepmother to Wentworth's children from his second wife, Arabella Holles. She died on 10 April 1688.

list.item: Ronald G. Asch, “Wentworth, Thomas, First Earl of Strafford (1593–1641), Lord Lieutenant of Ireland” (Oxford University Press, October 2009), https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/29056.

noteGrp.note: William Wentworth (1626-1695), 2nd Lord Raby, 2nd Earl Strafford, was born on 8 June 1626 to Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl Strafford, and his second wife, Arabella; he was their first child and only son. He married twice; first, Henrietta Maria Stanley and second, Henrietta de la Rochfoucauld. He died without issue on 16 October 1695, when the title Earl Strafford became extinct.

This is probably Philadelphia Wharton, the daughter of Robert and Elizabeth Carey. She was a lady-in-waiting to Princess Elizabeth, Queen of Bohemia and married Sir Thomas Wharton of Aske Hall in on 11 April 1611. They had two sons. She died in 1654 and was buried at St Agatha’s church, Easby.

Ralph Widdrington was the son of Lewis and Anne Widdrington of Cheesburn Grange, Northumberland, born in 1614/15. He attended Morpeth School and was then admitted to Christ's College, Cambridge in 1632. He was admitted to Gray's Inn in 1641, before being ordained and tutoring at Christ's, where he taught Thornton's younger brother, John Wandesford. He became Regius Professor of Greek in 1654 and was awarded a doctorate of Divinity in 1661. He died in Cambridge on 10 June 1688.

list.item: Hugh de Quehen, “Widdrington, Ralph (1614/15–1688), Scholar,” January 3, 2008, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/29355.

noteGrp.note: Sir Christopher Wyvill, 3rd Baronet of Constable Burton (1614-81), was baptised on 6 December 1614, the eldest son and heir of Marmaduke and Isabel Wyvill. He married Ursula Darcy on 12 December 1636 and the couple had 12 children, six of whom died before them. He wrote an elegy for Alice Thornton's brother, George Wandesford, on his death in 1651. He was elected MP for Richmond in 1659 and returned to the Long Parliament in 1660. He was buried with his wife, who died in 1680, at Masham on 8 February 1681.

list.item: Jill Seal Millman, “Wyvill, Sir Christopher, Third Baronet (Bap. 1614, d. 1681), Writer and Politician,” September 23, 2004, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/30179.

noteGrp.note: Mr Ande was a man living in the Ripon area in the late 1660s. He was married to Jane Wandesford, a cousin of Alice Thornton: possibly Jane Wandesford of Pickhill, daughter of Richard and Muriel Wandesford, born 4 March 1604. We have not been able to identify him further.

list.item: Collins, The Registers of Pickhill-cum-Roxby p. 8

noteGrp.note: This is probably Sir Philip Anstruther, the son of Sir Robert and Mary Anstruther born c. 1632. He inherited the Anstruther estate from his childless uncle John Anstruther in 1649. He was a Royalist colonel during the Wars of the Three Kingdoms and was captured at the final Royalist defeat at Worcester in 1651 and sequestered by Cromwell. He was reinstated under Charles II. He married Christian Lumsden and they had 7 sons and 3 daughters. He died in 1702.

list.item: Derek John Patrick, “Anstruther, Sir William, of That Ilk, Lord Anstruther (d. 1711), Judge,” September 23, 2004, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/589.
Anstruther, History of the family of Anstruther, pp. 11-12, 15-16

noteGrp.note: Allan Ascough was a kinsman of Alice Thornton's alive in the late 1660s. We have not been able to trace him further.

Sir Robert Barwick of Towlston was the son of Sir Robert Barwick, Recorder of York and Doncaster, and his second wife, Ursula, born c. 1633. He was admitted to Gray's Inn on 21 March 1641 and died on 16 June 1666.

list.item: Foster, The register of admissions to Gray's Inn, p. 231

noteGrp.note: Mary Batte (1641-xxxx) was the daughter of John and Martha Batte, baptised at Birstall on 26 October 1641. In Book 3, she is identified as the person involved with Anne Danby in the plot to break up the marriage between Thomas Comber and Nally Thornton. However, in Book 1, Thornton identifies Mary's sister Martha. We have not been able to trace Mary further and this may be a misremembered name by Thornton.

list.item: West Yorkshire Archive Service; Wakefield, Yorkshire, England; Yorkshire Parish Records; New Reference Number: WDP5/1/1/1

noteGrp.note: Cousin Beal was a female relation of Alice Thornton's who bought some goods in London for Thornton's mother's house at Hipswell before 1659. We have not been able to identify her further.

Gilbert Bennet, born c. 1599, matriculated Christ's College Cambridge in July 1617 and graduated with his MA in 1624. He was ordained priest at Peterborough in 1625 and then held the prebendary of Southwell, Nottinghamshire from 1660. He was vicar of Carnaby 1662-4, rector of Stonegrave in 1663 and prebend of York 1667-9. He was buried at Southwell, Nottinghamshire on 10 December 1669.
Mr Bradley was a married acquaintance of William Thornton, who was in the Hambleton area of North Yorkshire in 1652. We have been unable to identify him more precisely.
Mrs Browne was probably the wife of Thornton's possible cousin Benjamin Browne as they were present together at East Newton Hall in August 1662. We have not been able to identify her further.
[to add]
Dr Burton was made a trustee of Alice Thornton's estate, from her parents, to ensure that it would go to her children. No further identification made.
Butterfeild was a tenant of Alice Thornton's on her mother's land, who Alice allowed to stay until the end of the lease after her mother's death.

Sir Henry Cholmondeley (1609-66) was the second surviving son of Sir Richard Cholmondeley and his wife, Susanna. He was originally intended for the legal profession but was expelled from the Temple after 1634 and married the wealthy widow of George Twiselton, Katherine, in the late 1630s. They had one daughter. He was MP for New Malton 1641-8. Cholmondeley was sent to Tangier in spring 1666 to oversee the harbour development but died there not long afterwards. His body was brought home and he was buried at West Newton Grange on 30 June 1666.

list.item: M. W. Helms and Leonard Naylor, “CHOLMLEY, Sir Henry (1609-66), of West Newton Grange, Yorks.,” in History of Parliament Online, accessed January 13, 2023, http://www.historyofparliamentonline.org/volume/1660-1690/member/cholmley-sir-henry-1609-66.

noteGrp.note: William Clarkson was ordained Minister of Kirklington in October 1644 after the death of Robert Daggett. He was also chaplain to Lord Ferdinando Fairfax (1584-1648) in the 1640s. According to Thornton, he was very unpopular at Kirklington church as he preached against the Lord's prayer. He was replaced by Michael Syddall in 1646.

Mary Comber (1617-72) was the daughter of Brian and Alice Burton, baptised 14 September 1617 at Westerham, Kent. On 30 April 1638 she married Edward Hamden, a mercer, but he died less than a year later. They had one daughter. She then married James Comber of Allington in 1639. They had five children, two of whom survived to adulthood, James and Thomas, who went on to marry Nally Thornton. She died on 13 May 1672 and was buried two days later at Stonegrave by her son.

Ralph Crathorne was the first son and heir of Thomas and Catherine Crathorne, born in 1604. He married twice; first, Mary Wright, by whom he had a son and a daughter, and second, Margaret Thornton, sister of William Thornton; Alice Thornton's brother-in-law. With Margaret he had four children, three sons and a daughter. He was still alive in 1665.

list.item: Graves, 'Crathorne Pedigree' in History of Cleveland, p.107

noteGrp.note: Mr Culliss was a man to whom Gilbert Bennett, rector of Stonegrave from 1663, wished to marry one of his daughters. We have not been able to identify him further.

This is probably Elizabeth Dalton daughter of Marmaduke Wyvill, 2nd Baronet of Constable Burton, and his wife, Isabel. Elizabeth married Sir William, Dalton of Hauxwell Hall. They had 10 children, six sons and four daughters.

Edward Danby (1644-47) was the ninth child of Sir Thomas Danby and his wife, Katherine. He was born on 26 August 1644 when his parents were hiding at Middleham Castle, Yorkshire, and named after a sibling who had died as a baby in 1634. Alice Thornton, his aunt and godmother, was present for his birth and/or baptism. He died on 6 July 1647 and was buried at Leeds.

list.item: NYCRO, 'Dates of birth of the children of Sir Thos & Katherine Danby 1631-1645'. Danby family letters & papers c.1620-1687, ZS: Cunliffe-Lister Collection [MIC 2087/2087]
NYCRO, 'An old memorandum book of Mr John Gale's', [MIC 2087/2463]

noteGrp.note: Sir Abstrupus Danby (1655-1727) was the first son of Christopher and Anne Danby, born 27 December 1655. He was Alice Thornton's great-nephew. Before 1679 he married Judith Moone and they had a son. Abstrupus inherited an estate that was in debt and so sold off much of the family's property but came to be known as the 'Restorer' of his family. He was knighted in 1691 and became was MP for Aldborough 1698-1700. Defeated when he recontested his seat in 1701, he retained an active interest in Yorkshire politics until his death on 27 December 1727.

list.item: Eveline Cruickshanks and Ivar McGrath, “DANBY, Sir Abstrupus (1655-1727), of Masham, Nr. Ripon, Yorks.,” in History of Parliament Online, accessed January 16, 2023, https://www.historyofparliamentonline.org/volume/1690-1715/member/danby-sir-abstrupus-1655-1727.

noteGrp.note: Mr Danby bought a rent charge from William Thornton to pay debts in the late 1650s or 1660s. It has not been possible to identify him further.

Isabel Darcy was the daughter of Marmaduke Wyvill, second baronet of Burton Constable and his wife, Isabel. Before 1650 she married James Darcy of Sedbury Park, and they had three sons and four daughters. She died in 1660.

list.item: M. W. Helms, P. A. Bolton, and Paula Watson, “DARCY, Hon. James (1617-73), of Sedbury Park, Nr. Richmond, Yorks.,” in History of Parliament Online, accessed January 15, 2023, http://www.histparl.ac.uk/volume/1660-1690/member/darcy-hon-james-1617-73.

noteGrp.note: Lady Frances Darcy (1623-1670) was the daughter of Thomas Howard, 1st Earl of Berkshire and his wife Elizabeth, baptised 19 October 1623 at St. Martin-in-the-Fields, London. On 6 February 1650 she became the second wife of Lord Conyers Darcy, 2nd Earl Holdernesse. They had six children, three sons and three daughters. She was buried at Hornby on 10 April 1670.

list.item: M. W. Helms, P. A. Bolton, and Paula Watson, “DARCY, Hon. Conyers (1622-92), of Hornby Castle, Yorks.,” in History of Parliament Online, accessed January 15, 2023, http://www.historyofparliamentonline.org/volume/1660-1690/member/darcy-hon-conyers-1622-92.
Kitto, Register of St. Martin-in-the-Fields, p. 27.

noteGrp.note: John Darley held a bond with William Thornton for £1000 for the performance of covenants to Sir Henry Cholmondeley dated 7 August 1662. We have not been able to identify him with any certainty, but he was possibly related to William Thornton via William's mother, who was born Elizabeth Darley.
Robert Denton of Nawton was the son of Thomas and Barbara Denton, born c. 1615. He married Anne Maw in 1640 at Kirkdale and they had two sons and two daughters. He was still alive in 1665.

Timothy Dodsworth was the son of John and Frances Dodsworth of Thornton Watlass, baptised on 1 January 1622 at Thornton Watlass. He was Christopher Wandesford's servant in Ireland when he was Master of Rolls in the 1630s, and then entered Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge in 1637. He was admitted to Gray's Inn in January 1640. He married Dorothy Stringer on 14 April 1646 at St. Bartholomew the Less, London, and they had a son and a daughter. He died before 1673.

list.item: St. Bartholomew's Hospital Archives no: SBL10/1-11
Foster, Register of admissions to Gray's Inn, p. 224

noteGrp.note: This is probably Christopher Driffield of Easingwold, admitted to Gray's Inn in December 1650 and made Recorder of Ripon in 1673. He had at least one son, Christopher.

list.item: Foster, Register of admissions to Gray's Inn p. 255

noteGrp.note: This is probably Thomas Edmunds of Worsborough, Yorkshire, born c. 1596, secretary to the Earl of Strafford. He died on 9 January 1662.

This is probably Anne Fairfax, the daughter of Horace de Vere, Lord Tilbury and his wife Mary, born in 1617/18. She married Thomas Fairfax, 3rd Lord of Cameron on 20 June 1637 and they had two daughters. She and her husband retired to their estate at Nun Appleton, Yorkshire during the Interregnum. She died on 16 October 1666.

list.item: Jacqueline Eales, “Fairfax [Née Vere], Anne, Lady Fairfax (1617/18–1665), Noblewoman,” September 23, 2004, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/66848.

noteGrp.note: Cousin Fairfax was a female relation of Alice Thornton, possibly a descendant of Guy Fairfax of Gilling and Anne Thornton of East Newton who married in the mid-16th century. Anne Thornton was Alice's husband William's great-great-great-aunt. We have not been able to trace her any further.

Niece Fairfax was a female relation of Alice Thornton, probably a descendant of Guy Fairfax of Gilling and Anne Thornton of East Newton who married in the mid-16th century. Anne Thornton was Alice's husband William's great-great-great-aunt. We have not been able to trace her any further.

Thomas Fairfax, 3rd Lord of Cameron (1612-71) was the son of Ferdinando Fairfax, 2nd Lord Cameron of Denton, Yorkshire and his first wife Mary, born 17 January 1612. He was educated at St. John's College, Cambridge, matriculating in 1626 and entered Gray's Inn in 1628. He was commander-in-chief of the Parliamentarian forces during the First Civil War and leader of the New Model Army from 1645, but refused to participate in the trial and execution of Charles I. He married Anne, and they had two daughters, Mary and Anne (who died as a toddler). He and his wife retired to Nun Appleton, Yorkshire, after the King's execution and he died on 12 November 1671 after having been instrumental in the Restoration of Charles II.

list.item: Ian J. Gentles, “Fairfax, Thomas, Third Lord Fairfax of Cameron (1612–1671), Parliamentarian Army Officer,” January 3, 2008, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/9092.

noteGrp.note: Thomas Belasyse, 1st Earl Falconbridge was the son of Henry and Grace Belasyse, born at Newburgh Priory, near Coxwold, North Yorkshire in 1627/28. He married twice, first Mildred Saunderson in 1651, and then Mary, daughter of Lord Protector Oliver Cromwell, on 18 November 1657. He had no children. He inherited the title Viscount Falconbridge in 1653 and he took his seat as Lord Falconbridge in 1658. He became Lord Lieutenant of the North Riding and Durham in 1660. He died at Chiswick on 31 December 1700 and was buried at Coxwold on 31 January 1701.

list.item: Victor Stater, “Belasyse, Thomas, First Earl Fauconberg (1627/8–1700), Nobleman,” December 9, 2021, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/1978.

noteGrp.note: Charles Feild was a servant in Alice Thornton's household in the late 1660s. We have not been able to identify him further.

Normavill Fisher was a young man of 18 in the service of Anne Norton, Alice Thornton's aunt, at St. Nicholas, Richmond. He was perhaps born out of wedlock and also perhaps fathered a child. We have not been able to identify him further.

Thomas Flathers was the son of Marmaduke Flathers of Weston (later rector of Hemsworth) and his wife, a daughter of John Proctor of New Hall, near Otley. Born c. 1616, he was educated at Wakefield and Coxwold schools, and then Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge, graduating with a BA in 1635/6. He was ordained deacon in 1638 and priest in 1639. He was vicar of North Grimston 1640-62, and vicar of Lastingham and Rural Dean of Ryedale from September 1662. He died in 1686.

list.item: Brigg, Parish Registers of Otley, vol. 1, p. 38

noteGrp.note: Charles Fleetwood was the third son of Sir Miles and Anne Fleetwood of Aldwincle, Northamptonshire born c. 1618 (mistaken here for his father by Alice Thornton). Educated at Emmanuel College, Cambridge, he entered Gray's Inn on 30 November 1638. A parliamentarian soldier during the 1640s, leading troops at the Battle of Naseby, he rose to prominence during the Interregnum and became Commander in Chief of the parliamentary forces in Ireland in 1652, and Lord Deputy in 1654. He married three times, firstly Frances Smith, then Bridget, daughter of Oliver Cromwell and widow of Henry Ireton, previous Commander of Ireland. Bridget died in 1662 and in 1664 he married Mary, daughter of Sir John Coke. With Frances he had two children, Frances and Smith, and with Bridget three, two of whom survived to adulthood. He died on 4 October 1692 and was buried at Bunhill Fields, London.

list.item: Toby Barnard, “Fleetwood, Charles, Appointed Lord Fleetwood under the Protectorate (c. 1618–1692), Army Officer,” January 3, 2008, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/9684.

noteGrp.note: James Foxcraft was a friend or acquaintance of Christopher Wandesford living in Dublin in the early 1640s. He may have come to Ireland with Wandesford as one of his men, in which case, he was possibly the James Foxcraft of Bargrange born in 1594 at Leeds. We have not been able to trace him further.

noteGrp.note: William Foxley, born c. 1609, was Mayor of Hull in 1657 and 1676. He died on 24 September 1680. He is misnamed here by Thornton.

noteGrp.note: This is probably Lady Arabella Frankland, born c. 1638, daughter of Henry and Grace Belasyse. In 1662 she married Sir William Frankland of Thirkleby and they had nine children, four sons and a daughter surviving childhood. She died on 26 February 1687 and was buried at All Saints, Thirkleby.

noteGrp.note: Robert Garbutt was a man active in the Ryedale area in 1668. This might be the Robert Garbutt baptised at Bisdale Kirkham in 1617, or the one baptised at Coxwold in 1619. We have not been able to trace him further.

noteGrp.note: This is probably John Gibson (1630-1711) of Welborne, son of Sir John and Penelope Gibson, born 4 August 1630. He married Joan Pennyman on 30 September 1650, and they had 10 children, six sons and four daughters. He died on 20 November 1711.
Sir John Gibson of Welborne (1606-65) was the son of Sir John and Anne Gibson, born 20 January 1606. He married Penelope Woodall on 18 June 1629, and they had four sons. He died on 13 June 1665.

Thomas Gill of Barton was the second son of Thomas Gill and Elizabeth, daughter of Richard Wandesford of Pickhill, born c. 1632. He was a distant relation of Alice Thornton. The Pickhill Wandesfords became established in the later 16th century with Michael Wandesford, brother of Alice Thornton's great-great-great grandfather, Christopher Wandesford (d. 1540). An attorney, he married Elizabeth Smithson and they had 10 children, five sons and five daughters.
Susan Gosling was a servant in Alice Thornton's or her mother's household at Hipswell Hall in the 1650s. We have not traced her any further.
Mr Francis Graham was an acquaintance of Alice Thornton and Peter Samways in the late 1660s. He was possibly the Francis born c. 1614, brother of Ranald Graham of Nunnington.

Ranald Graham of London and Nunnington was the third son of Fergus and Sibill Graham of Plomp, born c. 1605. Apprenticed to a London merchant in 1622, he became a draper in Watling Street. By 1640 he was very wealthy and around this time he married Susannah Washington. The Grahams acquired Nunnington Hall in 1655 and Ranald and his wife moved from London. He became MP for Leominster in 1661 and Justice of the Peace of the North Riding of Yorkshire in 1662. He died without issue and his will was proved on 2 December 1685.

list.item: Edward Rowlands, “GRAHME, Ranald (c.1605-85), of Petty France, Westminster and Nunnington, Wath, Yorks.,” in History of Parliament Online, accessed January 15, 2023, http://www.histparl.ac.uk/volume/1660-1690/member/grahme-ranald-1605-85.

noteGrp.note: John Hall made two deeds with William Mitchell in April 1664. No further information on this man.

Thomas Hassell was the first son of Samuel and Mary Hassell of Hutton-on-Derwent, born c. 1627. He married Elizabeth Wood on 11 November 1647. He entered Gray's Inn in February 1648, becoming an Utter Barrister. He had seven children, three sons and four daughters. He was buried at St. Michael's, Malton on 27 October 1694.
Jane Heald was a servant or acquaintance of Thornton who was in the Ryedale area in the early 1630s. We have not been able to trace her further.
William Heard was the husband of Mary Breakes, a former servant of Alice Thornton. They married some time after Breakes left Thornton's service in 1668.
John Hicke was an old friend of William Thornton's who lent Alice Thornton £150 after William's death. We have not been able to trace him further.
Mrs Hickeringgill was a woman, perhaps a midwife, in the Richmond area in 1660. We have not been able to trace her further.
Elizabeth Hicks was a tenant of Alice and William Thornton's at Newton Park in the mid-1660s. We have not been able to trace her further.

Elizabeth Darley was the daughter of Sir William and Isabel Hildyard of Bishop Wilton. She married Richard Darley, the brother of William Thornton's mother, on 20 December 1632 at Bishop Wilton, making her Alice Thornton's aunt-by-marriage. She was also the niece of Catherine Hansby, Alice Thornton's great-grandmother, via her mother Isabel. Richard and Elizabeth had five children, four sons and a daughter. She was buried at Bishop Wilton.

list.item: York, Borthwick Institute. Parish registers for Bishop-Wilton, 1613-1901 PR/B/W 5, 9, 16-17

noteGrp.note: Sir William Hildyard of Bishop Wilton (1577-1632) was the eldest son of William and Anne Hildyard, baptised on 11 July 1577. He married Isabel Hansby, and they had six children; of which three daughters survived to adulthood. He died on 6 October 1632.

William Holland was the son of George Holland, merchant of Doncaster, born c. 1620. He was educated at Sheffield Grammar School and St John’s, Cambridge, gaining his BA in 1642. He was ordained Deacon and then Priest in 1646. He became vicar of Westerham, Kent in 1657. During his time as vicar of Westerham he taught a young Thomas Comber. Holland was vicar of both Great Wakering, Essex and All Hallows Staining, London between 1663 and 1677. He died in October 1677.
An unnamed daughter of William Holland. We have not been able to identify her more precisely.

Thomas Hoyle (1587-1650) was the son of Thomas Hoyle of Slaithwaite and his wife Elizabeth, baptised 29 January 1587. As a boy he was apprenticed to a merchant, Mr Topham of Micklegate, York. He married Elizabeth Maskewe in 1611 and they went on to have 13 children, all of whom except for one, Elizabeth (d. 1648) died before adulthood He married his second wife, Susanna, c.1641 and they had two sons – only John surviving to adulthood. Hoyle took up the Freedom of the city of York in 1612 and was warden of St Martin's, Micklegate in 1613. Rising up the civic ranks over the next 20 years, he became Alderman in 1626 and Mayor of York in 1632. A devout Presbyterian, he called for Charles I to be brought to justice but took no part in the king's trial. He hanged himself on 30 January 1650, exactly a year after the regicide, in his lodgings at Broad Sanctuary, Westminster.

list.item: David Scott, “Hoyle, Thomas (Bap. 1587, d. 1650), Politician,” January 3, 2008, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/66724.

Claire Cross, “A Man of Conscience in Seventeenth-Century Urban Politics: Alderman Hoyle of York,” in Public Duty and Private Conscience in Seventeenth-Century England: Essays Presented to G.E. Aylmer, ed. John Morrill, Paul Slack, and Daniel Woolf (Oxford University Press, 1993), 0, https://doi.org/10.1093/acprof:oso/9780198202295.003.0011.

noteGrp.note: Ellen Syddall married twice, first Christopher Hunton, steward to Alice Thornton's father, Christopher Wandesford, at Kirklington in the 1620s and 1630s; and second to Michael Syddall, minister of Kirklington from 1644-49 and St Anne's Catterick from 1645-58.
Mr Jackson is unidentified beyond Thornton’s account that she paid him to go to London to solicit on behalf of Thomas Comber for the living of Stonegrave in the mid-1660s.
Kendall was a woodworker in the Ryedale area active in the late 1660s. We have not been able to trace him further.
Mr Kerney was the Dublin landlord of one of the clerks of the Irish administration in the 1630s, who was still living in Dublin in the 1650s. We have not been able to trace him further.
Mr Lane was a friend or acquaintance of Alice Thornton in the mid-1660s. We have not been able to trace him further.

Philip Langdale was the son of William and Elizabeth Langdale of Langthorpe, born c. 1604. He married Anne Thornton, William Thornton's older half-sister; Alice Thornton's brother-in-law. They had one son.
Mary Lightfoote was the daughter of George and Daphne Lightfoote. We have not been able to identify her any further.
Cousin Lister was a relation of Alice Thornton who lived in the Ripon area. We have not been able to trace them further.

Charles Man was the second son of Charles Man, yeoman of Helmsley, Yorkshire, born c. 1643. He attended Helmsley and York schools, matriculating Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge on 1 June 1660, gaining his MA in 1667. He then became rector of Gilling, Yorkshire, and performed the marriage ceremony of Thomas and Alice Comber in 1668. He had a son, Charles, and was buried at Gilling on 28 March 1710.

noteGrp.note: George Masterman was a man living in the Stonegrave area in 1663. We have not been able to trace him further.

Frances Maude was the daughter of Christopher Wandesford, 1st Baronet of Kirklington and his wife Eleanor; Alice Thornton's niece. She married Robert Maude of West Riddleston and Ripon, and they had a son and two daughters. She died on 5 January 1690.
Sander (Alexander?) Metcalfe lived in the Yorkshire Dales in 1644. We have not been able to trace him further.

William Metcalfe was a solicitor, in the employ of William Wandesford, Alice Thornton's uncle. Metcalfe acted as William Thornton's agent in Ireland in the 1650s, tasked with locating Christopher Wandesford's lost will.
Anne Milbank, also known as Nan, was a servant in Alice Thornton's household in the late 1660s. We have not been able to trace her further.
William Mitchell made two deeds with John Hall in April 1664. No further information on this man.

Mr Morrett was a neighbour of Alice Thornton's when she lived at East Newton Hall. He acted as an appraiser of William Thornton's goods after his death in 1668. We have not been able to trace him further.

Mr Anthony Norton was a relative of Alice Thornton, who was in the Ryedale area in the late 1660s. Possibly a relation of Maulger and Anne Norton of St Nicholas Richmond, Thornton's maternal aunt and uncle and perhaps the same Anthony Norton mentioned in Alice Wandesford's will of 1659 as 'my cousin'.

list.item: TNA, Will of Dame Alice Wandesford, Widow of Hipswell, Yorkshire [PROB 11/298/634]

noteGrp.note: Mrs Norton may have been a relation of Alice Thornton's via her aunt and uncle Anne and Maulger Norton. She was alive in the late 1660s.

Sir Phelim Roe O'Neill was the eldest son of Sir Turlough Oge O'Neill of Kinnard and his wife, Catherine, born c. 1604. He was raised as a royal ward after his father's death and he entered Lincoln's Inn in 1618. Returning to Ireland in 1628, he returned to Catholicism. He was knighted by Thomas Wentworth, Lord Deputy of Ireland, in 1639. In 1641 he was one of the conspirators in the Irish Rebellion. He married three times: first, a daughter of Lord Iveagh, who died in 1641; secondly to Louise Preston. His third marriage was to Lady Jean Gordon with whom he had a son. After a military defeat in 1653 he was captured and executed on 10 March.

list.item: Jerrold I. Casway, “O’Neill, Sir Phelim Roe [Felim Ruadh] (1603–1653), Landowner and Insurgent,” January 3, 2008, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/20784
Micheal O’Siochru, “O’Neill, Sir Phelim,” in Dictionary of Irish Biography, accessed January 16, 2023, https://www.dib.ie/biography/oneill-sir-phelim-a6937.

persName.roleName: Sir; Earl of Danby; Marquess of Carmarthen; 1st Duke of Leeds

noteGrp.note: Sir Thomas Osborne (1632-1712), 1st Duke of Leeds (formerly Earl of Danby and Marquess of Carmarthen), was the second son of Sir Edward Osborne of Kiveton and his second wife, Anne. He became his father's heir in 1638 when his older brother was killed in an accident. His family property was sequestered after the battle of Marston Moor in 1644 and Osborne was exiled to Europe in the early 1650s. He married Bridget Bertie, and they had 11 children, three sons and eight daughters. He became High Sheriff of Yorkshire in 1661 and Lord Treasurer 1673-79. Impeached after the 'Popish Plot' in 1678, he spent the next six years in the Tower of London. He was then released on bail and played a key role in the plot against James II, advising William of Orange, who, on becoming king, made him President of the Privy Council. His cousin, Alice Thornton, wrote to him at least three times asking for his help: when he was Lord Treasurer in 1673 for assistance with arbitrating a dispute between herself and her brother, Christopher; in July 1689, seeking preferment for her son Robert; and in September 1689, seeking preferment for her son-in-law, Thomas Comber. He was dismissed in the mid-1690s and died on 26 July 1712 at his daughter Sophia’s house, Easton Neston, Northamptonshire. He was buried at Harthill, Yorkshire.

list.item: Mark Knights, “Osborne, Thomas, First Duke of Leeds (1632–1712), Politician,” October 4, 2008, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/20884.
London, BL Egerton MS 3337, f. 196: Letter from Alice Thornton to her cousin, Thomas Osborne, Lord Danby, Lord President of the Council, 28 July 1689

noteGrp.note: Mary Palmes was the daughter of William Eure, sixth Baron Eure of Malton. She married William Palmes, later MP for Malton, on 15 July 1663. They had four sons and four daughters.

noteGrp.note: Elizabeth Poore, also known as Bess, was a servant in Alice Wandesford's house at Hipswell, probably in the 1650s when Thornton and her husband were living there. We have not been able to trace her further.

Thomas Preston (1585-1655) was the second son of Christopher, 4th Viscount Gormanston, and his second wife, Catherine, born in 1585. Destined for a military career after attending the Irish college at Douai, he became a captain in the regiment of Henry O'Neill and served in the Netherlands. He married twice: first Clara van der Eycken of Flanders, with whom he had two sons, before her death in 1621; second, Marguerite of Namur with whom he probably had two more children, although these could have also been with his first wife. He frequently returned to Ireland in the 1640s and was appointed commander of the army of Leinster in 1642. He was made Viscount Tara and Governor of Waterford in 1650. He returned to Flanders and died there on 21 October 1655.

list.item: Micheal O’Siochru, “Preston, Thomas,” in Dictionary of Irish Biography, accessed January 16, 2023, https://www.dib.ie/biography/preston-thomas-a7493.

noteGrp.note: This is probably Sir James Preston (nicknamed Don Diego), second son of Thomas Preston, 1st Viscount Tara and his first wife Clara, who played a prominent military role in Ireland in the 1640s.

list.item: Micheal O’Siochru, “Preston, Thomas,” in Dictionary of Irish Biography, accessed January 16, 2023, https://www.dib.ie/biography/preston-thomas-a7493

noteGrp.note: Sir William Ryves was the sixth son of John and Elizabeth Ryves of Blandford, Dorset. He entered Middle Temple in 1593 and was called to the bar in 1600. He became Attorney General of Ireland in November 1619, a position he held until 1636 when he resigned to become justice of the court of King's Bench. He was MP for Belturbet, county Cavan, in 1634-5. He was Speaker of the Irish House of Lords in 1641-2. He married twice, first to a woman called Latham or Jackman, with whom he had four sons and four daughters, and second to Dorothy Waldron. He died in Dublin in 1648.

list.item: Terry Clavin, “Ryves, William,” in Dictionary of Irish Biography, accessed January 16, 2023, https://www.dib.ie/biography/ryves-sir-william-a7890.

noteGrp.note: Mr Roose was a clergyman who came to Stonegrave with Gilbert Bennett in 1666 to help him administer the parish. We have not been able to identify him further.

This is probably George Scott, son of George Scott, rector of Langton-on-Swale, born c. 1634. He attended Giggleswick School and was admitted to Christ's College, Cambridge in 1649, obtaining his BA in 1652 and MA in 1663. He was instituted to the rectory of Oswaldkirk in 1663, a position he held until his death c. 1700. He was also possibly the rector of Kirkby Wiske 1661-92. He had at least one son and two or more daughters.

Gilbert Sheldon (1598-1677) was the youngest son of Roger Sheldon, born 19 June 1598. His father was bailiff to Gilbert Talbot, the earl of Shrewsbury. He graduated from Trinity College, Oxford, in 1617, and got his MA from Cambridge in 1620. After entering All Souls as a fellow, he was ordained deacon by the Bishop of Oxford at Dorchester and probably ordained priest shortly afterwards. A royalist during the war, he was made Archbishop of Canterbury in 1663, a position he held until his death on 9 November 1677.

list.item: John Spurr, “Sheldon, Gilbert (1598–1677), Archbishop of Canterbury,” May 24, 2008, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/25304.

noteGrp.note: Mrs Sherwood was the wife of Elias Sherwood of Petergate, York, who owned lodgings in the late 1660s. A surviving indenture for the property on Petergate shows it was leased by one James Sherwood in 1662. She is perhaps Grace (née Bond) of Breighton who married Elias Sherwood at Bubwith, East Yorkshire, on 2 November 1665.

noteGrp.note: This is probably William Skinner, born c. 1627, merchant, alderman of Hull and mayor in 1664. He married Jane Foxley (d. 1652). He died on 19 September 1680.
Mr Smithson owned a shop in Richmond in 1660. He has not been traced further.

This is probably Dr Christopher Stone, ordained deacon in 1635 and priest in 1637 by Thomas Morton, bishop of Durham. He was instituted rector of Dalby in 1640 and Chancellor of York in 1662. He was rector of Beeford, 1669-85. He married Grace Robinson and had at least four children, three daughters and a son. He was buried at York Minster on 26 November 1686.
