noteGrp.note: Dame Sworre, possibly a midwife, was active in the Yorkshire area in the 1640s. Her title indicates that she was perhaps widowed. We have not been able to identify her further.

Charles Tancred of Arden Hall was born c. 1631, the son of William Tancred of Arden. He married Barbara Dalton, and they had 18 children, 12 sons and six daughters, of which only three survived to adulthood. In 1660 he was charged with threatening the peace of the Commonwealth. He died aged 80, on 26 February 1711 and was buried at All Saints, Hawnby in the same grave as his wife.

list.item: Gravestone of Charles Tancred, All Saints, Hawnby
Hunter, Familiae minorum gentium vol. 3 p. 913

noteGrp.note: Thomas Thompson was in the Ryedale area in 1668. We have not been able to identify him further.
Mrs Tirrill was the wife of Mr Tirrill of Hoddesdon, Hertfordshire, alive in 1664 when they attended the funeral of John Wandesford in Broxbourne. We have not been able to identify her further.
Mr Tully was a man living in or near Stonegrave in 1663. He was possibly George Tully, who resigned as prebend of Ripon in 1681; or Timothy Tully (1613-99), Canon of York from 1660.

Francis Thorp (1594-1665) was the eldest son of Roger and Elizabeth Thorpe of Birdsall, Yorkshire. He was admitted to Gray's Inn in 1611 and graduated from St John's College Cambridge in 1614. He was called to the bar in 1621. He was elected Recorder of Beverley in 1624. He married the twice-widowed Elizabeth Denton (née Oglethorpe). He was in London for much of the Wars of the Three Kingdoms. In 1645 he was elected 'recruiter' MP (i.e. filling a vacancy caused by a by-election) for Richmond. During the second English Civil War he played an important role organising Parliamentary forces in the North and was appointed serjeant-at-law in 1648. While named commissioner to try the king in January 1649 he took no part in it. Later in 1649 he was appointed to ride the northern circuit. On 1 June that year he was made one of the Barons of the Exchequer. He was elected MP for Beverley in 1654 but was prevented from sitting due to refusing to try fellow Yorkshiremen after Penruddock's rising. He took up his seat in 1659 and was reinstated as Baron of the Exchequer in 1660. He was buried at Bardsey Church on 7 June 1665.

list.item: David Scott, “Thorpe, Francis (Bap. 1594, d. 1665), Judge,” January 3, 2008, https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/27376.

noteGrp.note: Joyce Wandesford (1618-20), baptised at Kirklington 3 June 1618, was the third child of Christopher and Alice Wandesford. She died aged two and was buried on 11 September 1620 at Kirklington.

noteGrp.note: Jane Ande née Wandesford married one Mr Ande by the late 1660s. She may be Jane Wandesford of Pickhill, daughter of Richard and Muriel Wandesford, baptised 4 March 1604 at Pickhill-cum-Roxby.

noteGrp.note: Dr Henry Watkinson (1628-1712) was the son of Henry Watkinson. He was born in Ilkley and baptised on 24 April 1628 at St Peter's, Leeds. He attended Ilkley School and matriculated at St John's College, Cambridge in 1645, getting his BA in 1649. He obtained his doctorate in law from Padua in 1659. He was Chancellor of York 1673-1712. He married Elizabeth Hodgson (née Jennings) and they had a son, Christopher. He died on 25 April 1712 and was buried at St Cuthbert's, York.
Mrs Wattson was a midwife, friend or servant of Alice Thornton in the early 1660s. We have not been able to identify her further.
Anne Wellburne, known as Nan, was a maid in Alice Thornton's household in the early 1660s. We have not been able to identify her further.
This is possibly Richard Wilson, rector of Holy Trinity, Chester, ordained in 1621. A Royalist, he was absent in the early 1640s when he may have moved to St Michael's, Chester. He died in 1669.

Ezra Wollstone was a friend or acquaintance of Christopher Wandesford in Dublin in 1640. He is possibly the same gentleman of Newark that married Jane Halwell in Farndon, Nottinghamshire on 15 February 1643; but we have not been able to identify him with any more certainty.

noteGrp.note: Lady Ursula Wyvill was the second child and eldest daughter of Conyers Darcy, 1st Earl Holderness and his wife, Grace. She married Sir Christopher Wyvill, 3rd Baronet of Constable Burton on 12 December 1636 and bore 12 children, six of whom survived to adulthood. She died in 1680.

noteGrp.note: John Thornton (1633-69) was the son of Robert and Elizabeth Thornton of East Newton; William Thornton's younger brother. He was born on 5 October 1633 and baptised on 10 October at Stonegrave. He died on 22 May 1669 and was buried at Stonegrave the next day.

noteGrp.note: Anne Langdale was the third daughter of Robert and Dorothy Thornton of East Newton, baptised 3 December 1611 at Stonegrave. She was William Thornton's half-sister. She married Philip Langdale of Lanthorpe and they had one son.
